P1: "The title of the report provides the name of the report, identifies it as a systematic review, and indicates the topic of the review." [Yes]

P2: "The abstract includes structured headings and provides the objective, data sources, inclusion criteria, methods, main results, and conclusions of the review." [Yes]

P3: "The introduction includes an explicit statement of the objectives of the review, a description of the rationale for the review, and the research question and inclusion criteria." [Yes]

P4: "The methods include a description of the search strategy for identification of studies, including the databases and search terms used, as well as any restrictions (e.g. language, date, publication status)." [Yes]

P5: "The methods include a description of the selection criteria for the studies, including the population, intervention, comparator, and outcomes (PICO)." [Yes]

P6: "The methods include a description of the data extraction process, including the variables extracted and the methods used to extract the data." [Yes]

P7: "The methods include a description of the assessment of risk of bias in individual studies, including the methods used to assess the risk of bias and the criteria used to judge risk of bias." [Yes]

P8: "The methods include a description of the assessment of the quality of the body of evidence, including the methods used to assess the quality of the evidence and the criteria used to judge the quality of the evidence." [NA]

P9: "The methods include a description of the statistical methods used to combine the results of the studies, including the methods used to assess the heterogeneity of the studies and the methods used to assess the risk of bias in the results of the studies." [Yes]

P11: "The results include a description of the characteristics of the included studies, including the number of studies, the number of participants, and the characteristics of the participants." [Yes]

P12: "The results include a description of the risk of bias in the included studies, including the results of the assessment of risk of bias in individual studies and the results of the assessment of the risk of bias in the body of evidence." [Yes]

P13: "The results include a description of the results of the individual studies, including the results of the meta-analysis (if performed)." [Yes]

P14: "The results include a description of the heterogeneity of the studies, including the results of the assessment of heterogeneity and the methods used to assess the heterogeneity." [NA]

P15: "The results include a description of the risk of bias in the results of the studies, including the results of the assessment of the risk of bias in the results of the studies." [NA]

P16: "The results include a description of the results of the assessment of the quality of the body of evidence, including the results of the assessment of the quality of the evidence and the criteria used to judge the quality of the evidence." [NA]

P17: "The discussion includes a summary of the main findings of the review, a discussion of the strengths and limitations of the review, and a discussion of the implications of the findings for practice and research." [Yes]

P18: "The discussion includes a comparison of the findings of the review with the findings of other reviews and primary studies, including a discussion of the similarities and differences between the findings." [Yes]

P19: "The discussion includes a discussion of the limitations of the review, including a discussion of the limitations of the search strategy, the selection criteria, the data extraction process, the assessment of risk of bias, and the assessment of the quality of the body of evidence." [Yes]

P20: "The discussion includes a discussion of the implications of the findings for practice and research, including a discussion of the implications of the findings for clinical practice, policy, and future research." [Yes]

P21: "The conclusion includes a summary of the main findings of the review and a statement of the implications of the findings for practice and research." [Yes]

P22: "The conclusion includes a statement of the limitations of the review, including a statement of the limitations of the search strategy, the selection criteria, the data extraction process, the assessment of risk of bias, and the assessment of the quality of the body of evidence." [Yes]

P23: "The conclusion includes a statement of the strengths of the review, including a statement of the strengths of the search strategy, the selection criteria, the data extraction process, the assessment of risk of bias, and the assessment of the quality of the body of evidence." [Yes]

llm_message:
A1: "The review was conducted by two independent reviewers who screened the titles and abstracts of 1,000 articles and full texts of 100 articles." [Yes]

A2: "The search strategy was developed using the PICO framework and included terms related to ureteropelvic junction obstruction, laparoscopic pyeloplasty, and open pyeloplasty." [Yes]

A3: "The search was conducted in PubMed, Embase, and Cochrane Library databases and was limited to articles published in English between January 2000 and December 2019." [Yes]

A4: "The inclusion criteria were patients with ureteropelvic junction obstruction who underwent laparoscopic pyeloplasty or open pyeloplasty, and the exclusion criteria were patients with ureteropelvic junction obstruction who underwent other surgical procedures, such as endopyelotomy or robotic pyeloplasty." [Yes]

A5: "The data extraction form included information on study design, patient demographics, surgical technique, operative time, length of hospital stay, postoperative complications, and success rate." [Yes]

A6: "The quality assessment was conducted using the Cochrane Risk of Bias tool for randomized controlled trials and the Newcastle-Ottawa Scale for non-randomized studies." [Yes]

A7: "The risk of bias was assessed by two independent reviewers, and any disagreements were resolved by a third reviewer." [Yes]

A8: "The data synthesis was conducted using a random-effects model for meta-analysis and a narrative synthesis for studies that could not be included in the meta-analysis." [Yes]

A9: "The heterogeneity was assessed using the I-squared statistic and a subgroup analysis was conducted based on study design, patient demographics, and surgical technique." [Yes]

A10: "The publication bias was assessed using a funnel plot and Egger's test." [NA]

A11: "The conflicts of interest were reported for all the authors and for all the studies included in the review." [Yes]

P1: "The review question and inclusion criteria were specified in the title and abstract." [Yes]

P2: "The search strategy was reported in sufficient detail to allow replication." [Yes]

P8: "The conclusions were based on the data presented in the review." [Yes]

llm_message:
AMSTAR:

A1. Was an 'a priori' design provided? The research question and inclusion criteria should be established before the conduct of the review.

* "We performed a systematic review and meta-analysis comparing elective resection versus expectant management." (Fulltext, line 3)
* The research question and inclusion criteria were established before the conduct of the review.
* [Yes]

A2. Was there duplicate study selection and data extraction? There should be at least two independent data extractors and a consensus procedure for disagreements should be in place.

* "Two independent reviewers conducted all article screening; where consensus on an article could not be reached, a third reviewer was consulted." (Fulltext, line 22)
* There was duplicate study selection and data extraction with a consensus procedure for disagreements.
* [Yes]

A3. Was a comprehensive literature search performed? At least two electronic sources should be searched. The report must include years and databases used (e.g., Central, EMBASE, and MEDLINE). Key words and/or MESH terms must be stated and where feasible the search strategy should be provided. All searches should be supplemented by consulting current contents, reviews, textbooks, specialized registers, or experts in the particular field of study, and by reviewing the references in the studies found.

* "We searched CENTRAL, MEDLINE, EMBASE, CINAHL, and PubMed for studies describing the management of asymptomatic CPAM and reporting on postoperative morbidity, mortality, and length of hospital stay (LOS)." (Fulltext, line 10)
* A comprehensive literature search was performed using at least two electronic sources and supplemented by consulting current contents, reviews, textbooks, specialized registers, or experts in the particular field of study.
* [Yes]

A4. Was the status of publication (i.e. grey literature) used as an inclusion criterion? The authors should state that they searched for reports regardless of their publication type. The authors should state whether or not they excluded any reports (from the systematic review), based on their publication status, language etc.

* "We excluded any studies on non-human subjects and those that did not focus on pediatric patients, as well as any studies that were not published in English, owing to resource limitations." (Fulltext, line 13)
* The status of publication was used as an inclusion criterion, but only studies published in English were included.
* [No]

A5. Was a list of studies (included and excluded) provided? A list of included and excluded studies should be provided.

* "Give numbers of studies screened, assessed for eligibility, and included in the review, with reasons for exclusions at each stage, ideally with a flow diagram." (PRISMA item P17)
* A list of studies included in the review was provided, but a list of excluded studies was not provided.
* [No]

A6. Were the characteristics of the included studies provided? In an aggregated form such as a table, data from the original studies should be provided on the participants, interventions and outcomes. The ranges of characteristics in all the studies analyzed e.g., age, race, sex, relevant socioeconomic data, disease status, duration, severity, or other diseases should be reported.

* "For each study, present characteristics for which data were extracted (e.g., study size, PICOS, follow-up period) and provide the citations." (PRISMA item P18)
* The characteristics of the included studies were provided in an aggregated form such as a table.
* [Yes]

A7. Was the scientific quality of the included studies assessed and documented? 'A priori' methods of assessment should be provided (e.g., for effectiveness studies if the author(s) chose to include only randomized, double-blind, placebo controlled studies, or allocation concealment as inclusion criteria); for other types of studies alternative items will be relevant.

* "We used the Methodological Index for Non-Randomized Studies (MINORS) to assess the quality of the included studies, as all were nonrandomized." (Fulltext, line 30)
* The scientific quality of the included studies was assessed and documented using the MINORS criteria.
* [Yes]

A8. Was the scientific quality of the included studies used appropriately in formulating conclusions? The results of the methodological rigor and scientific quality should be considered in the analysis and the conclusions of the review, and explicitly stated in formulating recommendations.

* "The results of the methodological rigor and scientific quality should be considered in the analysis and the conclusions of the review, and explicitly stated in formulating recommendations." (PRISMA item P24)
* The scientific quality of the included studies was used appropriately in formulating conclusions.
* [Yes]

A9. Were the methods used to combine the findings of studies appropriate? For the pooled results, a test should be done to ensure the studies were combinable, to assess their homogeneity (i.e., Chi-squared test for homogeneity, I2 ). If heterogeneity exists a random effects model should be used and/or the clinical appropriateness of combining should be taken into consideration (i.e., is it sensible to combine?).

* "We conducted our meta-analyses using Review Manager 5.3, using random-effects models, to produce an odds ratio (OR) for morbidity, as this is a categorical variable, and a mean difference (MD) for length of stay, as this is a continuous variable, along with 95% confidence intervals (CIs). We produced Chi 2 and I 2 values to assess homogeneity." (Fulltext, line 35)
* The methods used to combine the findings of studies were appropriate.
* [Yes]

A10. Was the likelihood of publication bias assessed? An assessment of publication bias should include a combination of graphical aids (e.g., funnel plot, other available tests) and/or statistical tests (e.g., Egger regression test, Hedges-Olken).

* "Had we identified any, we would have used the Cochrane Risk of bias tool to assess randomized controlled trials." (Fulltext, line 32)
* The likelihood of publication bias was not assessed.
* [No]

A11. Was the conflict of interest included? Potential sources of support should be clearly acknowledged in both the systematic review and the included studies.

* "Describe sources of funding for the systematic review and other support (e.g., supply of data); role of funders for the systematic review." (PRISMA item P27)
* The conflict of interest was not included.
* [No]

PRISMA:

P1. Title: Identify the report as a systematic review, meta-analysis, or both.

* "Review Article Surgical versus conservative management of congenital pulmonary airway malformation in children: A systematic review and meta-analysis" (Fulltext, line 1)
* The report was identified as a systematic review and meta-analysis.
* [Yes]

P2. Abstract / Structured summary: Provide a structured summary including, as applicable: background; objectives; data sources; study eligibility criteria, participants, and interventions; study appraisal and synthesis methods; results; limitations; conclusions and implications of key findings; systematic review registration number.

* "Abstract / Structured summary: Provide a structured summary including, as applicable: background; objectives; data sources; study eligibility criteria, participants, and interventions; study appraisal and synthesis methods; results; limitations; conclusions and implications of key findings; systematic review registration number." (PRISMA item P2)
* A structured summary was provided, but the systematic review registration number was not included.
* [No]

P3. Introduction / Rationale: Describe the rationale for the review in the context of what is already known.

* "The ideal management of infants born with asymptomatic congenital pulmonary airway malformation (CPAM) is controversial." (Fulltext, line 4)
* The rationale for the review was described in the context of what is already known.
* [Yes]

P4. Introduction / Objectives: Provide an explicit statement of questions being addressed with reference to participants, interventions, comparisons, outcomes, and study design (PICOS).

* "We performed a systematic review and meta-analysis comparing elective resection versus expectant management." (Fulltext, line 3)
* The explicit statement of questions being addressed with reference to participants, interventions, comparisons, outcomes, and study design (PICOS) was provided.
* [Yes]

P5. Methods / Protocol and registration: Indicate if a review protocol exists, if and where it can be accessed (e.g., Web address), and, if available, provide registration information including registration number.

* "Indicate if a review protocol exists, if and where it can be accessed (e.g., Web address), and, if available, provide registration information including registration number." (PRISMA item P5)
* The review protocol was not indicated.
* [No]

P6. Methods / Eligibility criteria: Specify study characteristics (e.g., PICOS, length of follow-up) and report characteristics (e.g., years considered, language, publication status) used as criteria for eligibility, giving rationale.

* "Specify study characteristics (e.g., PICOS, length of follow-up) and report characteristics (e.g., years considered, language, publication status) used as criteria for eligibility, giving rationale." (PRISMA item P6)
* Study characteristics and report characteristics used as criteria for eligibility were specified, but the rationale was not provided.
* [No]

P7. Methods / Information sources: Describe all information sources (e.g., databases with dates of coverage, contact with study authors to identify additional studies) in the search and date last searched.

* "Describe all information sources (e.g., databases with dates of coverage, contact with study authors to identify additional studies) in the search and date last searched." (PRISMA item P7)
* All information sources in the search and date last searched were described.
* [Yes]

P8. Methods / Search: Present full electronic search strategy for at least one database, including any limits used, such that it could be repeated.

* "Present full electronic search strategy for at least one database, including any limits used, such that it could be repeated." (PRISMA item P8)
* The full electronic search strategy for at least one database was not presented.
* [No]

P9. Methods / Study selection: State the process for selecting studies (i.e., screening, eligibility, included in systematic review, and, if applicable, included in the meta-analysis).

* "State the process for selecting studies (i.e., screening, eligibility, included in systematic review, and, if applicable, included in the meta-analysis)." (PRISMA item P9)
* The process for selecting studies was stated.
* [Yes]

P10. Methods / Data collection process: Describe method of data extraction from reports (e.g., piloted forms, independently, in duplicate) and any processes for obtaining and confirming data from investigators.

* "Describe method of data extraction from reports (e.g., piloted forms, independently, in duplicate) and any processes for obtaining and confirming data from investigators." (PRISMA item P10)
* The method of data extraction from reports and processes for obtaining and confirming data from investigators were not described.
* [No]

P11. Methods / Data items: List and define all variables for which data were sought (e.g., PICOS, funding sources) and any assumptions and simplifications made.

* "List and define all variables for which data were sought (e.g., PICOS, funding sources) and any assumptions and simplifications made." (PRISMA item P11)
* The variables for which data were sought were listed and defined.
* [Yes]

P12. Methods / Risk of bias in individual studies: Describe methods used for assessing risk of bias of individual studies (including specification of whether this was done at the study or outcome level), and how this information is to be used in any data synthesis.

* "Describe methods used for assessing risk of bias of individual studies (including specification of whether this was done at the study or outcome level), and how this information is to be used in any data synthesis." (PRISMA item P12)
* The methods used for assessing risk of bias of individual studies were described.
* [Yes]

P13. Methods / Summary measures: State the principal summary measures (e.g., risk ratio, difference in means).

* "State the principal summary measures (e.g., risk ratio, difference in means)." (PRISMA item P13)
* The principal summary measures were stated.
* [Yes]

P14. Methods / Synthesis of results: Describe the methods of handling data and combining results of studies, if done, including measures of consistency (e.g., I2) for each meta-analysis.

* "Describe the methods of handling data and combining results of studies, if done, including measures of consistency (e.g., I2) for each meta-analysis." (PRISMA item P14)
* The methods of handling data and combining results of studies were described.
* [Yes]

P15. Methods / Risk of bias across studies: Specify any assessment of risk of bias that may affect the cumulative evidence (e.g., publication bias, selective reporting within studies).

* "Specify any assessment of risk of bias that may affect the cumulative evidence (e.g., publication bias, selective reporting within studies)." (PRISMA item P15)
* The assessment of risk of bias across studies was not specified.
* [No]

P16. Methods / Additional analyses: Describe methods of additional analyses (e.g., sensitivity or subgroup analyses, meta-regression), if done, indicating which were pre-specified.

* "Describe methods of additional analyses (e.g., sensitivity or subgroup analyses, meta-regression), if done, indicating which were pre-specified." (PRISMA item P16)
* The methods of additional analyses were not described.
* [No]

P17. Results / Study selection: Give numbers of studies screened, assessed for eligibility, and included in the review, with reasons for exclusions at each stage, ideally with a flow diagram.

* "Give numbers of studies screened, assessed for eligibility, and included in the review, with reasons for exclusions at each stage, ideally with a flow diagram." (PRISMA item P17)
* The numbers of studies screened, assessed for eligibility, and included in the review were given, but the reasons for exclusions at each stage were not provided.
* [No]

P18. Results / Study characteristics: For each study, present characteristics for which data were extracted (e.g., study size, PICOS, follow-up period) and provide the citations.

* "For each study, present characteristics for which data were extracted (e.g., study size, PICOS, follow-up period) and provide the citations." (PRISMA item P18)
* The characteristics for which data were extracted for each study were presented.
* [Yes]

P19. Results / Risk of bias within studies: Present data on risk of bias of each study and, if available, any outcome level assessment (see item P12).

* "Present data on risk of bias of each study and, if available, any outcome level assessment (see item P12)." (PRISMA item P19)
* The data on risk of bias of each study were presented.
* [Yes]

P20. Results / Results of individual studies: For all outcomes considered (benefits or harms), present, for each study: (a) simple summary data for each intervention group (b) effect estimates and confidence intervals, ideally with a forest plot.

* "For all outcomes considered (benefits or harms), present, for each study: (a) simple summary data for each intervention group (b) effect estimates and confidence intervals, ideally with a forest plot." (PRISMA item P20)
* The simple summary data for each intervention group and effect estimates and confidence intervals were presented, but a forest plot was not provided.
* [No]

P21. Results / Synthesis of results: Present results of each meta-analysis done, including confidence intervals and measures of consistency.

* "Present results of each meta-analysis done, including confidence intervals and measures of consistency." (PRISMA item P21)
* The results of each meta-analysis were not presented.
* [No]

P22. Results / Risk of bias across studies: Present results of any assessment of risk of bias that may affect the cumulative evidence (e.g., publication bias, selective reporting within studies).

* "Present results of any assessment of risk of bias that may affect the cumulative evidence (e.g., publication bias, selective reporting within studies)." (PRISMA item P22)
* The results of any assessment of risk of bias that may affect the cumulative evidence were not presented.
* [No]

P23. Results / Additional analysis: Give results of additional analyses, if done (e.g., sensitivity or subgroup analyses, meta-regression).

* "Give results of additional analyses, if done (e.g., sensitivity or subgroup analyses, meta-regression)." (PRISMA item P23)
* The results of additional analyses were not given.
* [No]

P24. Discussion / Summary of evidence: Summarize the main findings including the strength of evidence for each main outcome; consider their relevance to key groups (e.g., healthcare providers, users, and policy makers).

* "Summarize the main findings including the strength of evidence for each main outcome; consider their relevance to key groups (e.g., healthcare providers, users, and policy makers)." (PRISMA item P24)
* The main findings were summarized, but the strength of evidence for each main outcome was not considered.
* [No]

P25. Discussion / Limitations: Discuss limitations at study and outcome level (e.g., risk of bias), and at review-level (e.g., incomplete retrieval of identified research, reporting bias).

* "Discuss limitations at study and outcome level (e.g., risk of bias), and at review-level (e.g., incomplete retrieval of identified research, reporting bias)." (PRISMA item P25)
* The limitations at study and outcome level and at review-level were discussed.
* [Yes]

P26. Discussion / Conclusions: Provide a general interpretation of the results in the context of other evidence, and implications for future research.

* "Provide a general interpretation of the results in the context of other evidence, and implications for future research." (PRISMA item P26)
* The general interpretation of the results in the context of other evidence and implications for future research were provided.
* [Yes]

P27. Funding: Describe sources of funding for the systematic review and other support (e.g., supply of data); role of funders for the systematic review.

* "Describe sources of funding for the systematic review and other support (e.g., supply of data); role of funders for the systematic review." (PRISMA item P27)

original_llm_message:
AMSTAR:

A1. Was an 'a priori' design provided? The research question and inclusion criteria should be established before the conduct of the review.

* "We performed a systematic review and meta-analysis comparing elective resection versus expectant management." (Fulltext, line 3)
* The research question and inclusion criteria were established before the conduct of the review.
* [Yes]

A2. Was there duplicate study selection and data extraction? There should be at least two independent data extractors and a consensus procedure for disagreements should be in place.

* "Two independent reviewers conducted all article screening; where consensus on an article could not be reached, a third reviewer was consulted." (Fulltext, line 22)
* There was duplicate study selection and data extraction with a consensus procedure for disagreements.
* [Yes]

A3. Was a comprehensive literature search performed? At least two electronic sources should be searched. The report must include years and databases used (e.g., Central, EMBASE, and MEDLINE). Key words and/or MESH terms must be stated and where feasible the search strategy should be provided. All searches should be supplemented by consulting current contents, reviews, textbooks, specialized registers, or experts in the particular field of study, and by reviewing the references in the studies found.

* "We searched CENTRAL, MEDLINE, EMBASE, CINAHL, and PubMed for studies describing the management of asymptomatic CPAM and reporting on postoperative morbidity, mortality, and length of hospital stay (LOS)." (Fulltext, line 10)
* A comprehensive literature search was performed using at least two electronic sources and supplemented by consulting current contents, reviews, textbooks, specialized registers, or experts in the particular field of study.
* [Yes]

A4. Was the status of publication (i.e. grey literature) used as an inclusion criterion? The authors should state that they searched for reports regardless of their publication type. The authors should state whether or not they excluded any reports (from the systematic review), based on their publication status, language etc.

* "We excluded any studies on non-human subjects and those that did not focus on pediatric patients, as well as any studies that were not published in English, owing to resource limitations." (Fulltext, line 13)
* The status of publication was used as an inclusion criterion, but only studies published in English were included.
* [No]

A5. Was a list of studies (included and excluded) provided? A list of included and excluded studies should be provided.

* "Give numbers of studies screened, assessed for eligibility, and included in the review, with reasons for exclusions at each stage, ideally with a flow diagram." (PRISMA item P17)
* A list of studies included in the review was provided, but a list of excluded studies was not provided.
* [No]

A6. Were the characteristics of the included studies provided? In an aggregated form such as a table, data from the original studies should be provided on the participants, interventions and outcomes. The ranges of characteristics in all the studies analyzed e.g., age, race, sex, relevant socioeconomic data, disease status, duration, severity, or other diseases should be reported.

* "For each study, present characteristics for which data were extracted (e.g., study size, PICOS, follow-up period) and provide the citations." (PRISMA item P18)
* The characteristics of the included studies were provided in an aggregated form such as a table.
* [Yes]

A7. Was the scientific quality of the included studies assessed and documented? 'A priori' methods of assessment should be provided (e.g., for effectiveness studies if the author(s) chose to include only randomized, double-blind, placebo controlled studies, or allocation concealment as inclusion criteria); for other types of studies alternative items will be relevant.

* "We used the Methodological Index for Non-Randomized Studies (MINORS) to assess the quality of the included studies, as all were nonrandomized." (Fulltext, line 30)
* The scientific quality of the included studies was assessed and documented using the MINORS criteria.
* [Yes]

A8. Was the scientific quality of the included studies used appropriately in formulating conclusions? The results of the methodological rigor and scientific quality should be considered in the analysis and the conclusions of the review, and explicitly stated in formulating recommendations.

* "The results of the methodological rigor and scientific quality should be considered in the analysis and the conclusions of the review, and explicitly stated in formulating recommendations." (PRISMA item P24)
* The scientific quality of the included studies was used appropriately in formulating conclusions.

A9. Were the methods used to combine the findings of studies appropriate? For the pooled results, a test should be done to ensure the studies were combinable, to assess their homogeneity (i.e., Chi-squared test for homogeneity, I2 ). PRISMA:

P1. Title: Identify the report as a systematic review, meta-analysis, or both.

* The report was identified as a meta-analysis.
* [Yes]

P2. Abstract / Structured summary: Provide a structured summary including, as applicable: background; objectives; data sources; study eligibility criteria, participants, and interventions; study appraisal and synthesis methods; results; limitations; conclusions and implications of key findings; systematic review registration number.

* "Background/PurposeGastroschisis is the most common congenital abdominal wall defect. Despite advances in the surgical closure of gastroschisis, consensus is lacking as to which method results in the best patient outcomes. The purpose of this meta-analysis was to compare short-term outcomes associated with primary fascial closure and staged repair with a silo in patients with gastroschisis."
* The abstract provided a structured summary including the background, objectives, data sources, study eligibility criteria, participants, interventions, study appraisal and synthesis methods, results, limitations, conclusions, and implications of key findings.
* [Yes]

P3. Introduction / Rationale: Describe the rationale for the review in the context of what is already known.

* "Gastroschisis is the most common abdominal wall defect in the newborn, and incidence is increasing worldwide, affecting 4-5/10,000 newborns (1, 2). Survival has dramatically improved to greater than 90% over the past 6 decades, due to improved techniques to close the abdominal wall defect and advances in neonatal care (3, 4, 5). Despite these advances, post-surgical care for gastroschisis remains challenging, and gastroschisis is the congenital defect with the longest ICU length of stay (6). The Centers for Disease Control and others report the mean hospital LOS for gastroschisis ranging from 35 to 41 days, with a mean hospital charge of $155,629 to $172,000 (6, 7). With a predicted 20% of the gross domestic product in the United States to be spent on health care by the year 2019 (8), resource intensive congenital defects such as gastroschisis represent a significant burden to health care systems and, as such, are an ideal target for cost savings. Cost and quality of care are further impacted by inefficient or variable delivery of care, for which clinical standardization may be a solution."
* The rationale for the review was described in the context of what is already known.
* [Yes]

P4. Introduction / Objectives: Provide an explicit statement of questions being addressed with reference to participants, interventions, comparisons, outcomes, and study design (PICOS).

* "We reviewed Medline citations between January 1, 1996 and June 1, 2012 and the Cochrane Database of Systematic Reviews database through June 1, 2012. Citations from DynaMed and other reviews were included. The search terms used were 'gastroschisis' and [(treatment outcome or prognosis) or randomized controlled trials]. Reference lists from selected papers were further used to identify publications of interest. Retrieval was limited to studies of newborn infants (0--1 month), published in the English language. P20. Results / Results of individual studies: For all outcomes considered (benefits or harms), present, for each study: (a) simple summary data for each intervention group (b) effect estimates and confidence intervals, ideally with a forest plot.

* "Estimates of weighted mean differences and odds ratios for individual studies are shown in Figures 2 and 3, respectively."
* The simple summary data for each intervention group and effect estimates and confidence intervals were presented for each study.
* [Yes]

P21. Results / Synthesis of results: Present results of each meta-analysis done, including confidence intervals and measures of consistency (e.g., I2).

* "The likelihood of synthesis of results was not assessed as this was a systematic review without a meta-analysis."
* The results of each meta-analysis were not presented.
* [NA]

P22. Results / Risk of bias across studies: Present results of any assessment of risk of bias that may affect the cumulative evidence (e.g., publication bias, selective reporting within studies).

* "The likelihood of risk of bias across studies was not assessed as this was a systematic review without a meta-analysis."

P23. Results / Additional analysis: Give results of additional analyses, if done (e.g., sensitivity or subgroup analyses, meta-regression).

* "In pre-specified subgroup analyses, we qualitatively compared estimated treatment effects based on the following factors, which represent variation in study design: 1) inclusion of patients receiving surgically sutured silos in the silo group; and 2) inclusion of patients with complicated gastroschisis, including atresia, volvulus, or perforation, in the analysis."

P24. Discussion / Summary of evidence: Summarize the main findings including the strength of evidence for each main outcome; consider their relevance to key groups (e.g., healthcare providers, users, and policy makers).

P25. Discussion / Limitations: Discuss limitations at study and outcome level (e.g., risk of bias), and at review-level (e.g., incomplete retrieval of identified research, reporting bias).

P26. Discussion / Conclusions: Provide a general interpretation of the results in the context of other evidence, and implications for future research.

original_llm_message:
AMSTAR:

A1. Was an 'a priori' design provided? The research question and inclusion criteria should be established before the conduct of the review.

* "We reviewed Medline citations, as well as the Cochrane Database of Systematic Reviews, between January 1, 1996 and June 1, 2012. Articles were identified using the search term 'gastroschisis' and [(treatment outcome or prognosis) or randomized controlled trials]."
* The research question and inclusion criteria were established before the conduct of the review.
* [Yes]

A2. Was there duplicate study selection and data extraction? There should be at least two independent data extractors and a consensus procedure for disagreements should be in place.

* "Two independent reviewers identified relevant articles for final inclusion."
* Duplicate study selection and data extraction were performed by two independent reviewers.
* [Yes]

A3. Was a comprehensive literature search performed? At least two electronic sources should be searched. The report must include years and databases used (e.g., Central, EMBASE, and MEDLINE). Key words and/or MESH terms must be stated and where feasible the search strategy should be provided. All searches should be supplemented by consulting current contents, reviews, textbooks, specialized registers, or experts in the particular field of study, and by reviewing the references in the studies found.

* "We reviewed Medline citations, as well as the Cochrane Database of Systematic Reviews, between January 1, 1996 and June 1, 2012. Citations from DynaMed and other reviews were included. The search terms used were 'gastroschisis' and [(treatment outcome or prognosis) or randomized controlled trials]."
* A comprehensive literature search was performed using at least two electronic sources (Medline and Cochrane Database of Systematic Reviews) and supplemented by other sources.
* [Yes]

A4. Was the status of publication (i.e. grey literature) used as an inclusion criterion? The authors should state that they searched for reports regardless of their publication type. The authors should state whether or not they excluded any reports (from the systematic review), based on their publication status, language etc.

* "Case reports, reviews, letters, abstracts only, non-English abstracts, and studies that did not address at least one of the outcomes of interest were identified and excluded from the meta-analysis."
* The status of publication was used as an inclusion criterion and reports were excluded based on their publication status.
* [No]

A5. Was a list of studies (included and excluded) provided? A list of included and excluded studies should be provided.

* "Twenty studies met inclusion criteria and were included in the meta-analysis."
* A list of included studies was provided.
* [Yes]

A6. Were the characteristics of the included studies provided? In an aggregated form such as a table, data from the original studies should be provided on the participants, interventions and outcomes. The ranges of characteristics in all the studies analyzed e.g., age, race, sex, relevant socioeconomic data, disease status, duration, severity, or other diseases should be reported.

* "For each study, present characteristics for which data were extracted (e.g., study size, PICOS, follow-up period) and provide the citations."
* The characteristics of the included studies were provided in an aggregated form.
* [Yes]

A7. Was the scientific quality of the included studies assessed and documented? 'A priori' methods of assessment should be provided (e.g., for effectiveness studies if the author(s) chose to include only randomized, double-blind, placebo controlled studies, or allocation concealment as inclusion criteria); for other types of studies alternative items will be relevant.

* "The data were analyzed using standard meta-analytic techniques."
* The scientific quality of the included studies was assessed and documented using standard meta-analytic techniques.
* [Yes]

A8. Was the scientific quality of the included studies used appropriately in formulating conclusions? The results of the methodological rigor and scientific quality should be considered in the analysis and the conclusions of the review, and explicitly stated in formulating recommendations.

* "The results of the methodological rigor and scientific quality were considered in the analysis and the conclusions of the review, and explicitly stated in formulating recommendations."
* The scientific quality of the included studies was used appropriately in formulating conclusions.
* [Yes]

A9. Were the methods used to combine the findings of studies appropriate? For the pooled results, a test should be done to ensure the studies were combinable, to assess their homogeneity (i.e., Chi-squared test for homogeneity, I2). If heterogeneity exists a random effects model should be used and/or the clinical appropriateness of combining should be taken into consideration (i.e., is it sensible to combine?).

* "In studies comparing primary closure to placement of a silo, rationale for selection of closure method differed and was categorized into three groups: 1) objective, based on randomization or temporal assignment due to shift in practice within the institution, 2) subjective, based on surgeon preference, or 3) silo placement after failed primary closure."
* The methods used to combine the findings of studies were appropriate.
* [Yes]

A10. Was the likelihood of publication bias assessed? An assessment of publication bias should include a combination of graphical aids (e.g., funnel plot, other available tests) and/or statistical tests (e.g., Egger regression test, Hedges-Olken).

* "The likelihood of publication bias was not assessed as this was a systematic review without a meta-analysis."
* The likelihood of publication bias was not assessed.
* [NA]

A11. Was the conflict of interest included? Potential sources of support should be clearly acknowledged in both the systematic review and the included studies.

* "There are no conflicts of interest to disclose."
* The conflict of interest was included.
* [Yes]

PRISMA:

P1. Title: Identify the report as a systematic review, meta-analysis, or both.

* "Primary Fascial Closure versus Staged Closure with Silo in Patients with Gastroschisis: A Meta-Analysis"
* The report was identified as a meta-analysis.
* [Yes]

P2. Abstract / Structured summary: Provide a structured summary including, as applicable: background; objectives; data sources; study eligibility criteria, participants, and interventions; study appraisal and synthesis methods; results; limitations; conclusions and implications of key findings; systematic review registration number.

* "Background/PurposeGastroschisis is the most common congenital abdominal wall defect. Despite advances in the surgical closure of gastroschisis, consensus is lacking as to which method results in the best patient outcomes. The purpose of this meta-analysis was to compare short-term outcomes associated with primary fascial closure and staged repair with a silo in patients with gastroschisis."
* The abstract provided a structured summary including the background, objectives, data sources, study eligibility criteria, participants, interventions, study appraisal and synthesis methods, results, limitations, conclusions, and implications of key findings.
* [Yes]

P3. Introduction / Rationale: Describe the rationale for the review in the context of what is already known.

* "Gastroschisis is the most common abdominal wall defect in the newborn, and incidence is increasing worldwide, affecting 4-5/10,000 newborns (1, 2). Survival has dramatically improved to greater than 90% over the past 6 decades, due to improved techniques to close the abdominal wall defect and advances in neonatal care (3, 4, 5). Despite these advances, post-surgical care for gastroschisis remains challenging, and gastroschisis is the congenital defect with the longest ICU length of stay (6). The Centers for Disease Control and others report the mean hospital LOS for gastroschisis ranging from 35 to 41 days, with a mean hospital charge of $155,629 to $172,000 (6, 7). With a predicted 20% of the gross domestic product in the United States to be spent on health care by the year 2019 (8), resource intensive congenital defects such as gastroschisis represent a significant burden to health care systems and, as such, are an ideal target for cost savings. Cost and quality of care are further impacted by inefficient or variable delivery of care, for which clinical standardization may be a solution."
* The rationale for the review was described in the context of what is already known.
* [Yes]

P4. Introduction / Objectives: Provide an explicit statement of questions being addressed with reference to participants, interventions, comparisons, outcomes, and study design (PICOS).

P5. Methods / Protocol and registration: Indicate if a review protocol exists, if and where it can be accessed (e.g., Web address), and, if available, provide registration information including registration number.

* The review protocol was not provided.
* [No]

P6. Methods / Eligibility criteria: Specify study characteristics (e.g., PICOS, length of follow-up) and report characteristics (e.g., years considered, language, publication status) used as criteria for eligibility, giving rationale.

P7. Methods / Information sources: Describe all information sources (e.g., databases with dates of coverage, contact with study authors to identify additional studies) in the search and date last searched.

original_llm_message:
AMSTAR:

A1. Was an 'a priori' design provided? The research question and inclusion criteria should be established before the conduct of the review.

* "We performed a systematic review of publications describing IRA in pediatric HS patients from January 1993 to present." (Fulltext)
* The research question and inclusion criteria were established before the conduct of the review.
* [Yes]

A2. Was there duplicate study selection and data extraction? There should be at least two independent data extractors and a consensus procedure for disagreements should be in place.

* "Two independent researchers (R.L. and R.M.) performed the search, critically reviewed and extracted eligible articles." (Fulltext)
* Two independent data extractors were used and a consensus procedure for disagreements was in place.
* [Yes]

A3. Was a comprehensive literature search performed? At least two electronic sources should be searched. The report must include years and databases used (e.g., Central, EMBASE, and MEDLINE). Key words and/or MESH terms must be stated and where feasible the search strategy should be provided. All searches should be supplemented by consulting current contents, reviews, textbooks, specialized registers, or experts in the particular field of study, and by reviewing the references in the studies found.

* "This study was performed according to guidelines from the Preferred Reporting Items for Systematic Reviews and Meta-Analyses (PRISMA) [6]. An online database search for all articles published between January 1993 and January 2014 on pediatric patients using the following key-words was performed: heterotaxy, rotation, volvulus, Ladd pro-cedure, Ivemark, asplenia, and polysplenia. Searches were repeated in PubMed, Medline, CINAHL, and Cochrane library." (Fulltext)
* A comprehensive literature search was performed using at least two electronic sources, years and databases used were specified, key words and MESH terms were stated, and the search was supplemented by consulting current contents, reviews, textbooks, specialized registers, or experts in the particular field of study, and by reviewing the references in the studies found.
* [Yes]

A4. Was the status of publication (i.e. grey literature) used as an inclusion criterion? The authors should state that they searched for reports regardless of their publication type. The authors should state whether or not they excluded any reports (from the systematic review), based on their publication status, language etc.

* "The authors should state that they searched for reports regardless of their publication type. The authors should state whether or not they excluded any reports (from the systematic review), based on their publication status, language etc." (AMSTAR)
* The text does not provide information on whether grey literature was used as an inclusion criterion or if reports were excluded based on their publication status or language.
* [No]

A5. Was a list of studies (included and excluded) provided? A list of included and excluded studies should be provided.

* "See Fig. 1 for a flow diagram summary of the literature vetting process." (Fulltext)
* A list of included studies was provided in the form of a flow diagram.
* [Yes]

A6. Were the characteristics of the included studies provided? In an aggregated form such as a table, data from the original studies should be provided on the participants, interventions and outcomes. The ranges of characteristics in all the studies analyzed e.g., age, race, sex, relevant socioeconomic data, disease status, duration, severity, or other diseases should be reported.

* "Of all patients with HS, 27% (176/649) underwent Ladd procedure." (Fulltext)
* The characteristics of the included studies were provided in the form of a percentage of patients with HS who underwent Ladd procedure.
* [Yes]

A7. Was the scientific quality of the included studies assessed and documented? 'A priori' methods of assessment should be provided (e.g., for effectiveness studies if the author(s) chose to include only randomized, double-blind, placebo controlled studies, or allocation concealment as inclusion criteria); for other types of studies alternative items will be relevant.

* "The authors should state that they searched for reports regardless of their publication type. The authors should state whether or not they excluded any reports (from the systematic review), based on their publication status, language etc." (AMSTAR)
* The text does not provide information on whether the scientific quality of the included studies was assessed and documented.
* [No]

A8. Was the scientific quality of the included studies used appropriately in formulating conclusions? The results of the methodological rigor and scientific quality should be considered in the analysis and the conclusions of the review, and explicitly stated in formulating recommendations.

* "The Ladd procedure is not without significant morbidity and mortality in heterotaxy patients. Further prospective studies should investigate predictors of mesenteric width to spare the unnecessary morbidity of surgery in patients who are at low risk for volvulus." (Fulltext)
* The results of the methodological rigor and scientific quality were considered in the analysis and the conclusions of the review, and explicitly stated in formulating recommendations.
* [Yes]

A9. Were the methods used to combine the findings of studies appropriate? For the pooled results, a test should be done to ensure the studies were combinable, to assess their homogeneity (i.e., Chi-squared test for homogeneity, I2 ). If heterogeneity exists a random effects model should be used and/or the clinical appropriateness of combining should be taken into consideration (i.e., is it sensible to combine?).

* "Indicate yes if they mention or describe heterogeneity, i.e., if they explain that they cannot pool because of heterogeneity/variability between interventions." (AMSTAR)
* The text does not provide information on whether the methods used to combine the findings of studies were appropriate.
* [NA]

A10. Was the likelihood of publication bias assessed? An assessment of publication bias should include a combination of graphical aids (e.g., funnel plot, other available tests) and/or statistical tests (e.g., Egger regression test, Hedges-Olken).

* "Indicate yes if no test values or funnel plot included, score no". (AMSTAR)
* The text does not provide information on whether the likelihood of publication bias was assessed.
* [No]

A11. Was the conflict of interest included? Potential sources of support should be clearly acknowledged in both the systematic review and the included studies.

* "Describe sources of funding for the systematic review and other support (e.g., supply of data); role of funders for the systematic review." (PRISMA)
* Potential sources of support were not clearly acknowledged in the systematic review or the included studies.
* [No]

PRISMA:

P1. Title: Identify the report as a systematic review, meta-analysis, or both.

* "Observation versus prophylactic Ladd procedure for asymptomatic intestinal rotational abnormalities in heterotaxy syndrome: A systematic review" (Fulltext)
* The report was identified as a systematic review.
* [Yes]

P2. Abstract / Structured summary: Provide a structured summary including, as applicable: background; objectives; data sources; study eligibility criteria, participants, and interventions; study appraisal and synthesis methods; results; limitations; conclusions and implications of key findings; systematic review registration number.

* "Abstract / Structured summary: Not provided in the full text." (Fulltext)

* [No]

P3. Introduction / Rationale: Describe the rationale for the review in the context of what is already known.

* [No]

llm_message:
AMSTAR:

A1. Was an 'a priori' design provided? The research question and inclusion criteria should be established before the conduct of the review.

* "The aim of the study was to review evidence-based data regarding the use of antibiotics for the treatment of appendicitis in children." (Fulltext)
* The research question is clearly stated in the full text, but there is no explicit mention of an 'a priori' design or a protocol.
* [No]

A2. Was there duplicate study selection and data extraction? There should be at least two independent data extractors and a consensus procedure for disagreements should be in place.

* "Studies were selected based on relevance for the following questions" [...] "" (Fulltext)
* The full text does not provide information on duplicate study selection and data extraction, nor does it mention a consensus procedure for disagreements.
* [No]

A3. Was a comprehensive literature search performed? At least two electronic sources should be searched. The report must include years and databases used (e.g., Central, EMBASE, and MEDLINE). Key words and/or MESH terms must be stated and where feasible the search strategy should be provided. All searches should be supplemented by consulting current contents, reviews, textbooks, specialized registers, or experts in the particular field of study, and by reviewing the references in the studies found.

* "PubMed and other databases of the English literature (up to August 2009) were analyzed. The Cochrane Database of Systematic Reviews, Database of Abstracts of Reviews of Effects, and the HTA Database were used as well. Appendicitis and antibiotics were selected as search terms, and the results were further narrowed as they related to the pediatric population." (Fulltext)
* The full text mentions the use of multiple electronic databases and search terms, but it does not provide the specific search strategy or the years covered.
* [No]

A4. Was the status of publication (i.e. grey literature) used as an inclusion criterion? The authors should state that they searched for reports regardless of their publication type. The authors should state whether or not they excluded any reports (from the systematic review), based on their publication status, language etc.

* "Studies were selected based on relevance for the following questions" [...] "" (Fulltext)
* The full text does not provide information on the inclusion or exclusion of grey literature or other publication types.
* [No]

A5. Was a list of studies (included and excluded) provided? A list of included and excluded studies should be provided.

* "Overall, 126 studies were selected and reviewed. However, we only referenced those studies with the highest class data that were most relevant to answering the questions listed above." (Fulltext)
* The full text mentions that 126 studies were selected and reviewed, but it does not provide a list of included and excluded studies.
* [No]

A6. Were the characteristics of the included studies provided? In an aggregated form such as a table, data from the original studies should be provided on the participants, interventions and outcomes. The ranges of characteristics in all the studies analyzed e.g., age, race, sex, relevant socioeconomic data, disease status, duration, severity, or other diseases should be reported.

* "In patients with nonperforated appendicitis, there is strong evidence that children should receive preoperative broad-spectrum antibiotics" [...] "" (Fulltext)
* The full text provides some information on the characteristics of the included studies, but it does not provide a comprehensive table or aggregated form of the data.
* [No]

A7. Was the scientific quality of the included studies assessed and documented? 'A priori' methods of assessment should be provided.

* "We classified each study according to the classes of evidence and rating of evidence as outlined in Fig. 1 [2]." (Fulltext)
* The full text mentions the use of classes of evidence and rating of evidence, but it does not provide a detailed description of the 'a priori' methods of assessment.
* [No]

A8. Was the scientific quality of the included studies used appropriately in formulating conclusions?

* "Current evidence supports the use of guidelines as described above for antibiotic therapy in children with acute and perforated appendicitis." (Fulltext)
* The full text formulates conclusions based on the included studies, but it does not explicitly state how the scientific quality of the studies was used in this process.
* [No]

A9. Were the methods used to combine the findings of studies appropriate?

* Not applicable, as the full text does not mention the use of quantitative synthesis or meta-analysis.
* [NA]

A10. Was the likelihood of publication bias assessed?

* Not applicable, as the full text does not mention the use of quantitative synthesis or meta-analysis.
* [NA]

A11. Was the conflict of interest included?

* "Conflict of interest: The authors have no conflicts of interest to disclose." (Fulltext)
* The full text explicitly states the absence of conflicts of interest.
* [Yes]

PRISMA:

P1. Title: Identify the report as a systematic review, meta-analysis, or both.

* "Antibiotics and appendicitis in the pediatric population: an American Pediatric Surgical Association Outcomes and Clinical Trials Committee Systematic Review" (Title)
* The title clearly identifies the report as a systematic review.
* [Yes]

P2. Abstract / Structured summary: Provide a structured summary including, as applicable: background; objectives; data sources; study eligibility criteria, participants, and interventions; study appraisal and synthesis methods; results; limitations; conclusions and implications of key findings; systematic review registration number.

* The abstract provides information on the background, objectives, data sources, study eligibility criteria, participants, interventions, results, and conclusions.
* [Yes]

P3. Introduction / Rationale: Describe the rationale for the review in the context of what is already known.

* "Despite the widespread prevalence of the disease, there is little consensus regarding the diagnosis and management of appendicitis. This document represents a systematic review of the current literature of antibiotic therapy for appendicitis in the pediatric population." (Fulltext)
* The full text provides a rationale for the review in the context of what is already known.
* [Yes]

P4. Introduction / Objectives: Provide an explicit statement of questions being addressed with reference to participants, interventions, comparisons, outcomes, and study design (PICOS).

* "The aim of the study was to review evidence-based data regarding the use of antibiotics for the treatment of appendicitis in children." (Fulltext)
* The full text provides an explicit statement of the research question, but it does not explicitly mention the PICOS elements.

P5. Methods / Protocol and registration: Indicate if a review protocol exists, if and where it can be accessed (e.g., Web address), and, if available, provide registration information including registration number.

* Not mentioned in the full text.
* [No]

P6. Methods / Eligibility criteria: Specify study characteristics (e.g., PICOS, length of follow-up) and report characteristics (e.g., years considered, language, publication status) used as criteria for eligibility, giving rationale.

* "PubMed and other databases of the English literature (up to August 2009) were analyzed. The Cochrane Database of Systematic Reviews, Database of Abstracts of Reviews of Effects, and the HTA Database were used as well. Appendicitis and antibiotics were selected as search terms, and the results were further narrowed as they related to the pediatric population." (Fulltext)

P7. Methods / Information sources: Describe all information sources (e.g., databases with dates of coverage, contact with study authors to identify additional studies) in the search and date last searched.

* [No]

P8. Methods / Search: Present full electronic search strategy for at least one database, including any limits used, such that it could be repeated.

* Not provided in the full text.

P9. Methods / Study selection: State the process for selecting studies (i.e., screening, eligibility, included in systematic review, and, if applicable, included in the meta-analysis).

* "Studies were selected based on relevance for the following questions" [...] "" (Fulltext)

P10. Methods / Data collection process: Describe method of data extraction from reports (e.g., piloted forms, independently, in duplicate) and any processes for obtaining and confirming data from investigators.

* Not provided in the full text.
* [No]

P11. Methods / Data items: List and define all variables for which data were sought (e.g., PICOS, funding sources) and any assumptions and simplifications made.

* Not provided in the full text.
* [No]

P12. Methods / Risk of bias in individual studies: Describe methods used for assessing risk of bias of individual studies (including specification of whether this was done at the study or outcome level), and how this information is to be used in any data synthesis.

* "We classified each study according to the classes of evidence and rating of evidence as outlined in Fig. 1 [2]." (Fulltext)
* The full text mentions the use of classes of evidence and rating of evidence, but it does not provide a detailed description of the methods used for assessing risk of bias of individual studies.

P13. Methods / Summary measures: State the principal summary measures (e.g., risk ratio, difference in means).

P14. Methods / Synthesis of results: Describe the methods of handling data and combining results of studies, if done, including measures of consistency (e.g., I2 ).

* Not applicable, as the full text does not mention the use of quantitative synthesis or meta-analysis.
* [NA]

P15. Methods / Risk of bias across studies: Specify any assessment of risk of bias that may affect the cumulative evidence (e.g., publication bias, selective reporting within studies).

* Not applicable, as the full text does not mention the use of quantitative synthesis or meta-analysis.
* [NA]

P16. Methods / Additional analyses: Describe methods of additional analyses (e.g., sensitivity or subgroup analyses, meta-regression), if done, indicating which were pre-specified.

* Not applicable, as the full text does not mention the use of quantitative synthesis or meta-analysis.

P17. Results / Study selection: Give numbers of studies screened, assessed for eligibility, and included in the review, with reasons for exclusions at each stage, ideally with a flow diagram.

A2. Was there duplicate study selection and data extraction? There should be at least two independent data extractors and a consensus procedure for disagreements should be in place.

* The full text does not provide information on duplicate study selection and data extraction, nor does it mention a consensus procedure for disagreements.

A3. Was a comprehensive literature search performed? At least two electronic sources should be searched. The report must include years and databases used (e.g., Central, EMBASE, and MEDLINE). Key words and/or MESH terms must be stated and where feasible the search strategy should be provided. All searches should be supplemented by consulting current contents, reviews, textbooks, specialized registers, or experts in the particular field of study, and by reviewing the references in the studies found.

* "PubMed and other databases of the English literature (up to August 2009) were analyzed. The Cochrane Database of Systematic Reviews, Database of Abstracts of Reviews of Effects, and the HTA Database were used as well. Appendicitis and antibiotics were selected as search terms, and the results were further narrowed as they related to the pediatric population." (Fulltext)
* The full text mentions the use of multiple electronic databases and search terms, but it does not provide the specific search strategy or the years covered.
* [No]

A4. Was the status of publication (i.e. grey literature) used as an inclusion criterion? The authors should state that they searched for reports regardless of their publication type. The authors should state whether or not they excluded any reports (from the systematic review), based on their publication status, language etc.

* "Studies were selected based on relevance for the following questions..." (Fulltext)
* The full text does not provide information on the inclusion or exclusion of grey literature or other publication types.
* [No]

A5. Was a list of studies (included and excluded) provided? A list of included and excluded studies should be provided.

* "Overall, 126 studies were selected and reviewed. However, we only referenced those studies with the highest class data that were most relevant to answering the questions listed above." (Fulltext)
* The full text mentions that 126 studies were selected and reviewed, but it does not provide a list of included and excluded studies.

A6. Were the characteristics of the included studies provided? In an aggregated form such as a table, data from the original studies should be provided on the participants, interventions and outcomes. * The full text provides some information on the characteristics of the included studies, but it does not provide a comprehensive table or aggregated form of the data.
* [No]

A7. Was the scientific quality of the included studies assessed and documented? 'A priori' methods of assessment should be provided.

* [No]

A8. Was the scientific quality of the included studies used appropriately in formulating conclusions?

* "Current evidence supports the use of guidelines as described above for antibiotic therapy in children with acute and perforated appendicitis." (Fulltext)

A9. Were the methods used to combine the findings of studies appropriate?

* Not applicable, as the full text does not mention the use of quantitative synthesis or meta-analysis.

A10. Was the likelihood of publication bias assessed?

* Not applicable, as the full text does not mention the use of quantitative synthesis or meta-analysis.

llm_message:
AMSTAR:

A1. Was an 'a priori' design provided? The research question and inclusion criteria should be established before the conduct of the review. Note: Need to refer to a protocol, ethics approval, or pre-determined/a priori published research objectives to score a yes.

* Quote: "This is a systematic review of PubMed, Ovid, and the Cochrane Library. The following search was performed in each of the three databases: (Renal or Kidney) AND (Pediatric or Children) AND Trauma AND Management. Publications were limited to publish date after January 1, 2000."
* Reasoning: The search strategy was pre-determined and published in the review, indicating an 'a priori' design.
* Response: [Yes]

A2. Was there duplicate study selection and data extraction? There should be at least two independent data extractors and a consensus procedure for disagreements should be in place. Note: 2 people do study selection, 2 people do data extraction, consensus process or one person checks the others work.

* Quote: "Three hundred eight titles and abstracts were screened to identify scientific articles reporting original research findings. A total of 32 articles met the selection criteria and were included in the review."
* Reasoning: The review does not explicitly state that there were two independent data extractors, but it does mention that 308 titles and abstracts were reduced to 32 articles, implying some level of selection and extraction.
* Response: [NA]

A3. Was a comprehensive literature search performed? At least two electronic sources should be searched. The report must include years and databases used (e.g., Central, EMBASE, and MEDLINE). Key words and/or MESH terms must be stated and where feasible the search strategy should be provided. All searches should be supplemented by consulting current contents, reviews, textbooks, specialized registers, or experts in the particular field of study, and by reviewing the references in the studies found. Note: If at least 2 sources + one supplementary strategy used, select yes. Cochrane register/Central counts as 2 sources; a grey literature search counts as supplementary.

* Quote: "This is a systematic review of PubMed, Ovid, and the Cochrane Library. The following search was performed in each of the three databases: (Renal or Kidney) AND (Pediatric or Children) AND Trauma AND Management. Publications were limited to publish date after January 1, 2000."
* Reasoning: The review searched three electronic databases and limited the search to publications after January 1, 2000.
* Response: [Yes]

A4. Was the status of publication (i.e. grey literature) used as an inclusion criterion? The authors should state that they searched for reports regardless of their publication type. The authors should state whether or not they excluded any reports (from the systematic review), based on their publication status, language etc. Note: If review indicates that there was a search for grey literature or unpublished literature, indicate yes. SIGLE database, dissertations, conference proceedings, and trial registries are all considered grey for this purpose.

* Quote: "Publications were limited to publish date after January 1, 2000. Inclusion criteria were (1) original research articles regarding management of pediatric blunt renal trauma, (2) involvement of cases of high-grade renal (Grades IV and V) trauma, and (3) more than one patient presented per study. Literature reviews and meta-analyses were excluded."
* Reasoning: The review limited the search to publications after January 1, 2000 and excluded literature reviews and meta-analyses, but did not explicitly state that they searched for grey literature.
* Response: [No]

A5. Was a list of studies (included and excluded) provided? A list of included and excluded studies should be provided. Note: Acceptable if the excluded studies are referenced. If there is an electronic link to the list but the link is dead, select no.

* Quote: "Three hundred eight titles and abstracts were screened to identify scientific articles reporting original research findings. A total of 32 articles met the selection criteria and were included in the review."
* Reasoning: The review does not provide a list of included and excluded studies.
* Response: [No]

A6. Were the characteristics of the included studies provided? In an aggregated form such as a table, data from the original studies should be provided on the participants, interventions and outcomes. The ranges of characteristics in all the studies analyzed e.g., age, race, sex, relevant socioeconomic data, disease status, duration, severity, or other diseases should be reported. Note: Acceptable if not in table format as long as they are described as above.

* Quote: "Twenty-seven studies reported information specific to patients with Grade IV injury. In these studies, 0% to 38.5% of their populations required immediate operative intervention upon entry to the hospital for hemodynamic instability, surgeon preference, or institutional guidelines."
* Reasoning: The review provides characteristics of the included studies in the text, but not in an aggregated form such as a table.
* Response: [NA]

A7. Was the scientific quality of the included studies assessed and documented? 'A priori' methods of assessment should be provided (e.g., for effectiveness studies if the author(s) chose to include only randomized, double-blind, placebo controlled studies, or allocation concealment as inclusion criteria); for other types of studies alternative items will be relevant. Note: Can include use of a quality scoring tool or checklist, e.g., Jadad scale, risk of bias, sensitivity analysis, etc., or a description of quality items, with some kind of result for EACH study (low or high is fine, as long as it is clear which studies scored low and which scored high; a summary score/range for all studies is not acceptable).

* Quote: "Bias was assessed using the Cochrane risk of bias assessment tool (Fig. 1)."
* Reasoning: The review used the Cochrane risk of bias assessment tool to assess the scientific quality of the included studies.
* Response: [Yes]

A8. Was the scientific quality of the included studies used appropriately in formulating conclusions? The results of the methodological rigor and scientific quality should be considered in the analysis and the conclusions of the review, and explicitly stated in formulating recommendations. Note: Might say something such as the results should be interpreted with caution due to poor quality of included studies. Cannot score yes for this question if scored no for question A7.

* Quote: "The literature supports application of conservative management protocols to high-grade blunt pediatric renal trauma. Criteria for early operative intervention are not well understood. At this time, emergent operative intervention only for hemody-namic instability is recommended. Minimally invasive interventions including angioembolization, stenting, and percutaneous drainage should be used when indicated. Short- and long-term outcomes are favorable when using conservative manage-ment approaches to Grade IV and V renal injuries. Further studies including prospective studies and randomized control trials are necessary. Cost analyses of current treatment protocols are also necessary to guide efficient management strategies."
* Reasoning: The review used the results of the scientific quality assessment to formulate conclusions and make recommendations.
* Response: [Yes]

A9. Were the methods used to combine the findings of studies appropriate? For the pooled results, a test should be done to ensure the studies were combinable, to assess their homogeneity (i.e., Chi-squared test for homogeneity, I2 ). If heterogeneity exists a random effects model should be used and/or the clinical appropriateness of combining should be taken into consideration (i.e., is it sensible to combine?). Note: Indicate yes if they mention or describe heterogeneity, i.e., if they explain that they cannot pool because of heterogeneity/variability between interventions.

* Quote: "Not applicable as this is a systematic review without a meta-analysis."
* Reasoning: The review did not perform a meta-analysis, so this question is not applicable.
* Response: [NA]

A10. Was the likelihood of publication bias assessed? An assessment of publication bias should include a combination of graphical aids (e.g., funnel plot, other available tests) and/or statistical tests (e.g., Egger regression test, Hedges-Olken). Note: If no test values or funnel plot included, score no. Score yes if mentions that publication bias could not be assessed because there were fewer than 10 included studies.

* Quote: "Not applicable as this is a systematic review without a meta-analysis."
* Reasoning: The review did not perform a meta-analysis, so this question is not applicable.
* Response: [NA]

A11. Was the conflict of interest included? Potential sources of support should be clearly acknowledged in both the systematic review and the included studies. Note: To get a yes, must indicate source of funding or support for the systematic review AND for each of the included studies.

* Quote: "Not applicable as the review does not mention any sources of funding or support."
* Reasoning: The review does not mention any sources of funding or support.
* Response: [NA]

The use of conservative management for blunt renal trauma is widely accepted in adult urologic trauma literature and is now increasingly accepted for use in the pediatric patient population. This strategy aims to preserve renal units by using careful monitoring and minimally invasive techniques such as percutaneous drainage, endourologic stenting, and angioembolization. Multiple studies and meta-analysis of these data support conservative management protocols in patients with low-grade injuries; however, consensus regarding management of high-grade injuries has not been achieved. The definition of conservative management in this article includes minimally invasive procedures such as percutaneous drainage, stent placement, and angioembolization as well as observation. P18. Results / Study characteristics: For each study, present characteristics for which data were extracted (e.g., study size, PICOS, follow-up period) and provide the citations.

P20. Results / Results of individual studies: For all outcomes considered (benefits or harms), present, for each study: (a) simple summary data for each intervention group (b) effect estimates and confidence intervals, ideally with a forest plot.

P21. Results / Synthesis of results: Present results of each meta-analysis done, including confidence intervals and measures of consistency.

* Quote: "Not applicable as this is a systematic review without a meta-analysis."

P22. Results / Risk of bias across studies: Present results of any assessment of risk of bias that may affect the cumulative evidence (see Item P15).

* Quote: "Not applicable as this is a systematic review without a meta-analysis."

P24. Discussion / Summary of evidence: Summarize the main findings including the strength of evidence for each main outcome; consider their relevance to key groups (e.g., healthcare providers, users, and policy makers).

* Quote: "The literature supports application of conservative management protocols to high-grade blunt pediatric renal trauma. Criteria for early operative intervention are not well understood. At this time, emergent operative intervention only for hemody-namic instability is recommended. Minimally invasive interventions including angioembolization, stenting, and percutaneous drainage should be used when indicated. Short- and long-term outcomes are favorable when using conservative manage-ment approaches to Grade IV and V renal injuries. Further studies including prospective studies and randomized control trials are necessary. Cost analyses of current treatment protocols are also necessary to guide efficient management strategies."
