P4. Introduction / Objectives: Provide an explicit statement of questions being addressed with reference to participants, interventions, comparisons, outcomes, and study design (PICOS).

* "The purpose of this review is to update the use of MIS in pediatric oncological surgery over the past five years."
* The introduction provides a clear objective for the review, but it does not explicitly mention participants, interventions, comparisons, outcomes, or study design.
* [No]

P5. Methods / Protocol and registration: Indicate if a review protocol exists, if and where it can be accessed (e.g., Web address), and, if available, provide registration information including registration number.

* "Our review focuses on the data from the past five years from 2009 to 2014 to try to delineate the new upcoming events in the field of MIS in childhood cancer."
* The review does not mention the existence of a review protocol or registration information.
* [No]

P6. Methods / Eligibility criteria: Specify study characteristics (e.g., PICOS, length of follow-up) and report characteristics (e.g., years considered, language, publication status) used as criteria for eligibility, giving rationale.

* "References for this review were identified by PubMed searches using appropriate search terms for each section (minimally invasive surgery, laparoscopy, thoracoscopy, childhood/children/pediatric cancer). Articles were also identified by searching the authors own files. Only papers published in English language were reviewed. The final list of references was generated on the basis of their publication date and their relevance in the scope of this review."
* The review mentions using PubMed as a search source and only reviewing papers published in English, but it does not explicitly mention other study characteristics or report characteristics used as criteria for eligibility.
* [No]

P7. Methods / Information sources: Describe all information sources (e.g., databases with dates of coverage, contact with study authors to identify additional studies) in the search and date last searched.

* "References for this review were identified by PubMed searches using appropriate search terms for each section (minimally invasive surgery, laparoscopy, thoracoscopy, childhood/children/pediatric cancer)."
* The review mentions using PubMed as a search source, but it does not mention any other information sources or the date last searched.
* [No]

P8. Methods / Search: Present full electronic search strategy for at least one database, including any limits used, such that it could be repeated.

* "References for this review were identified by PubMed searches using appropriate search terms for each section (minimally invasive surgery, laparoscopy, thoracoscopy, childhood/children/pediatric cancer)."
* The review does not present the full electronic search strategy for PubMed or any other database.
* [No]

P9. Methods / Study selection: State the process for selecting studies (i.e., screening, eligibility, included in systematic review, and, if applicable, included in the meta-analysis).

* "The final list of references was generated on the basis of their publication date and their relevance in the scope of this review."
* The review does not explicitly state the process for selecting studies.
* [No]

P10. Methods / Data collection process: Describe method of data extraction from reports (e.g., piloted forms, independently, in duplicate) and any processes for obtaining and confirming data from investigators.

* "The final list of references was generated on the basis of their publication date and their relevance in the scope of this review."
* The review does not mention the data collection process.
* [No]

P11. Methods / Data items: List and define all variables for which data were sought (e.g., PICOS, funding sources) and any assumptions and simplifications made.

* "The final list of references was generated on the basis of their publication date and their relevance in the scope of this review."
* The review does not mention the data items sought.
* [No]

P12. Methods / Risk of bias in individual studies: Describe methods used for assessing risk of bias of individual studies (including specification of whether this was done at the study or outcome level), and how this information is to be used in any data synthesis.

* "The final list of references was generated on the basis of their publication date and their relevance in the scope of this review."
* The review does not mention assessing risk of bias of individual studies.
* [No]

P13. Methods / Summary measures: State the principal summary measures (e.g., risk ratio, difference in means).

* "The final list of references was generated on the basis of their publication date and their relevance in the scope of this review."
* The review does not mention the principal summary measures.
* [No]

P14. Methods / Synthesis of results: Describe the methods of handling data and combining results of studies, if done, including measures of consistency (e.g., I2) for each meta-analysis.

* "The final list of references was generated on the basis of their publication date and their relevance in the scope of this review."
* The review does not mention handling data or combining results of studies.
* [No]

P15. Methods / Risk of bias across studies: Specify any assessment of risk of bias that may affect the cumulative evidence (e.g., publication bias, selective reporting within studies).

* "The final list of references was generated on the basis of their publication date and their relevance in the scope of this review."
* The review does not mention assessing risk of bias across studies.
* [No]

P16. Methods / Additional analyses: Describe methods of additional analyses (e.g., sensitivity or subgroup analyses, meta-regression), if done, indicating which were pre-specified.

* "The final list of references was generated on the basis of their publication date and their relevance in the scope of this review."
* The review does not mention additional analyses.
* [No]

P17. Results / Study selection: Give numbers of studies screened, assessed for eligibility, and included in the review, with reasons for exclusions at each stage, ideally with a flow diagram.

* "The final list of references was generated on the basis of their publication date and their relevance in the scope of this review."
* The review does not provide numbers of studies screened, assessed for eligibility, and included in the review, nor does it provide reasons for exclusions at each stage or a flow diagram.
* [No]

P18. Results / Study characteristics: For each study, present characteristics for which data were extracted (e.g., study size, PICOS, follow-up period) and provide the citations.

* "The final list of references was generated on the basis of their publication date and their relevance in the scope of this review."
* The review does not present the characteristics of the studies included in the review.
* [No]

P19. Results / Risk of bias within studies: Present data on risk of bias of each study and, if available, any outcome level assessment (see item P12).

* "The final list of references was generated on the basis of their publication date and their relevance in the scope of this review."
* The review does not present data on risk of bias of each study.
* [No]

P20. Results / Results of individual studies: For all outcomes considered (benefits or harms), present, for each study: (a) simple summary data for each intervention group (b) effect estimates and confidence intervals, ideally with a forest plot.

* "The final list of references was generated on the basis of their publication date and their relevance in the scope of this review."
* The review does not present the results of individual studies.
* [No]

P21. Results / Synthesis of results: Present results of each meta-analysis done, including confidence intervals and measures of consistency.

* "The final list of references was generated on the basis of their publication date and their relevance in the scope of this review."
* The review does not present the results of any meta-analyses.
* [No]

P22. Results / Risk of bias across studies: Present results of any assessment of risk of bias that may affect the cumulative evidence (e.g., publication bias, selective reporting within studies).

* "The final list of references was generated on the basis of their publication date and their relevance in the scope of this review."
* The review does not present results of any assessment of risk of bias across studies.
* [No]

P23. Results / Additional analysis: Give results of additional analyses, if done (e.g., sensitivity or subgroup analyses, meta-regression).

* "The final list of references was generated on the basis of their publication date and their relevance in the scope of this review."
* The review does not mention or present results of any additional analyses.
* [No]

P24. Discussion / Summary of evidence: Summarize the main findings including the strength of evidence for each main outcome; consider their relevance to key groups (e.g., healthcare providers, users, and policy makers).

* "Conclusion MIS is a promising method for removal of thoracic and abdominal malignancies as long as oncological principles are strictly followed. Long-term follow-up is mandatory to further delineate objective indications."
* The review provides a brief summary of the main findings and the relevance of the findings to key groups, but it does not explicitly mention the strength of evidence for each main outcome.
* [No]

P25. Discussion / Limitations: Discuss limitations at study and outcome level (e.g., risk of bias), and at review-level (e.g., incomplete retrieval of identified research, reporting bias).

* "The review does not mention any limitations at study, outcome, or review-level."
* [No]

P26. Discussion / Conclusions: Provide a general interpretation of the results in the context of other evidence, and implications for future research.

* "Conclusion MIS is a promising method for removal of thoracic and abdominal malignancies as long as oncological principles are strictly followed. Long-term follow-up is mandatory to further delineate objective indications."
* The review provides a brief interpretation of the results in the context of other evidence and implications for future research, but it does not explicitly mention other evidence or provide a detailed interpretation of the results.
* [No]

P27. Funding: Describe sources of funding for the systematic review and other support (e.g., supply of data); role of funders for the systematic review.

* "The review does not mention sources of funding for the systematic review or other support."
* [No]

llm_message:
AMSTAR:

A1. Was an 'a priori' design provided? The research question and inclusion criteria should be established before the conduct of the review.

*Quote*: "The purpose of this study is to determine whether the safety and efficacy of URS now warrant it being considered the standard of care and the first line of therapy in the management of pediatric urolithiasis."

*Reasoning*: The research question is clearly stated in the introduction of the article.

*Response*: [Yes]

A2. Was there duplicate study selection and data extraction? There should be at least two independent data extractors and a consensus procedure for disagreements should be in place.

*Quote*: "A systematic review of articles written about ureteroscopy (URS) in the contemporary urological literature (19902009) on PubMed was undertaken."

*Reasoning*: The authors conducted a systematic review of articles on PubMed, but it is not explicitly stated if there were at least two independent data extractors and a consensus procedure for disagreements.

*Response*: [NA]

A3. Was a comprehensive literature search performed? At least two electronic sources should be searched. The report must include years and databases used (e.g., Central, EMBASE, and MEDLINE). Key words and/or MESH terms must be stated and where feasible the search strategy should be provided. All searches should be supplemented by consulting current contents, reviews, textbooks, specialized registers, or experts in the particular field of study, and by reviewing the references in the studies found.

*Quote*: "A systematic review of articles written about ureteroscopy (URS) in the contemporary urological literature (19902009) on PubMed was undertaken."

*Reasoning*: The authors conducted a systematic review of articles on PubMed, but it is not explicitly stated if they searched other electronic sources or supplemented the search with other strategies.

*Response*: [No]

A4. Was the status of publication (i.e. grey literature) used as an inclusion criterion? The authors should state that they searched for reports regardless of their publication type. The authors should state whether or not they excluded any reports (from the systematic review), based on their publication status, language etc.

*Quote*: "The success rates and complications of pediatric ureteroscopic procedures were abstracted from the identified publications and the results were tabulated and compared with the success rates of shockwave lithotripsy."

*Reasoning*: The authors did not explicitly state if they searched for grey literature or if they excluded any reports based on their publication status.

*Response*: [No]

A5. Was a list of studies (included and excluded) provided? A list of included and excluded studies should be provided.

*Quote*: "A total of 27 papers that met the inclusion criteria for this review were identified and the data were abstracted."

*Reasoning*: The authors identified and abstracted data from 27 papers, but it is not explicitly stated if they provided a list of included and excluded studies.

*Response*: [NA]

A6. Were the characteristics of the included studies provided? In an aggregated form such as a table, data from the original studies should be provided on the participants, interventions and outcomes. The ranges of characteristics in all the studies analyzed e.g., age, race, sex, relevant socioeconomic data, disease status, duration, severity, or other diseases should be reported.

*Quote*: "Over the past 20 years, the results of 832 pediatric patients (mean age, 9.4 years) managed with URS to treat stones have been published in the urological literature."

*Reasoning*: The authors provided the mean age of the patients, but it is not explicitly stated if they reported the ranges of characteristics of the included studies.

*Response*: [NA]

A7. Was the scientific quality of the included studies assessed and documented? 'A priori' methods of assessment should be provided (e.g., for effectiveness studies if the author(s) chose to include only randomized, double-blind, placebo controlled studies, or allocation concealment as inclusion criteria); for other types of studies alternative items will be relevant.

*Quote*: "The success rate of URS is 93.4% (compared with 80.3% for ESWL). The complication rate associated with the URS procedures is 5.9% (compared with 8.4% for ESWL)."

*Reasoning*: The authors compared the success rate and complication rate of URS and ESWL, but it is not explicitly stated if they assessed and documented the scientific quality of the included studies.

*Response*: [No]

A8. Was the scientific quality of the included studies used appropriately in formulating conclusions? The results of the methodological rigor and scientific quality should be considered in the analysis and the conclusions of the review, and explicitly stated in formulating recommendations.

*Quote*: "In this systematic review of the literature, URS is shown to be safer and more efficacious than ESWL in the management of pediatric urolithiasis."

*Reasoning*: The authors concluded that URS is safer and more efficacious than ESWL in the management of pediatric urolithiasis, but it is not explicitly stated if they considered the results of the methodological rigor and scientific quality of the included studies in formulating their conclusions.

*Response*: [No]

A9. Were the methods used to combine the findings of studies appropriate? For the pooled results, a test should be done to ensure the studies were combinable, to assess their homogeneity (i.e., Chi-squared test for homogeneity, I2 ). If heterogeneity exists a random effects model should be used and/or the clinical appropriateness of combining should be taken into consideration (i.e., is it sensible to combine?).

*Quote*: "The success rate of URS is 93.4% (compared with 80.3% for ESWL). The complication rate associated with the URS procedures is 5.9% (compared with 8.4% for ESWL)."

*Reasoning*: The authors compared the success rate and complication rate of URS and ESWL, but it is not explicitly stated if they assessed the homogeneity of the studies or used appropriate methods to combine the findings.

*Response*: [No]

A10. Was the likelihood of publication bias assessed? An assessment of publication bias should include a combination of graphical aids (e.g., funnel plot, other available tests) and/or statistical tests (e.g., Egger regression test, Hedges-Olken).

*Quote*: "The success rate of URS is 93.4% (compared with 80.3% for ESWL). The complication rate associated with the URS procedures is 5.9% (compared with 8.4% for ESWL)."

*Reasoning*: The authors compared the success rate and complication rate of URS and ESWL, but it is not explicitly stated if they assessed the likelihood of publication bias.

*Response*: [No]

A11. Was the conflict of interest included? Potential sources of support should be clearly acknowledged in both the systematic review and the included studies.

*Quote*: "For correspondence: Dr. Pramod P. Reddy, 3333 Burnet Ave., Surgical Services, Division of Pediatric Urology (MC5037), Cincinnati Childrens Hospital Medical Center, Cincinnati, OH 45229, USA. E-mail: pramod.reddy@cchmc.org"

*Reasoning*: The authors provided their contact information, but it is not explicitly stated if they acknowledged potential sources of support.

*Response*: [NA]

PRISMA:

P1. Title: Identify the report as a systematic review, meta-analysis, or both.

*Quote*: "Ureteroscopy: The standard of care in the management of upper tract urolithiasis in children"

*Reasoning*: The title of the article suggests that it is a review article, but it is not explicitly stated if it is a systematic review or meta-analysis.

*Response*: [No]

P2. Abstract / Structured summary: Provide a structured summary including, as applicable: background; objectives; data sources; study eligibility criteria, participants, and interventions; study appraisal and synthesis methods; results; limitations; conclusions and implications of key findings; systematic review registration number.

*Quote*: "Abstract Objectives: Advances in technology and the continued evolution in the design of ureteroscopes now permit a primary endoscopic approach to the upper urinary tract of pediatric patients on a routine basis to treat a diverse group of conditions that include urolithiasis, hematuria and strictures. The purpose of this review article is to demonstrate that ureteroscopic lithotripsy is now to be considered the standard of care in the management of upper tract urolithiasis in the pediatric patient, replacing shockwave lithotripsy (ESWL) as the first line of therapy. Additionally, the article will discuss the available endoscopic equipment and the lessons learned over the years to optimize the success of these procedures in children."

*Reasoning*: The abstract provides a structured summary of the article, including the background, objectives, data sources, study eligibility criteria, participants, interventions, and results.

*Response*: [Yes]

P3. Introduction / Rationale: Describe the rationale for the review in the context of what is already known.

*Quote*: "The earliest documented instance of an ureteroscopic procedure was interestingly performed in a pediatric patient by Drs. Young and McKay in 1929 on a 2-week-old baby with posterior urethral valves. They used a pediatric cystoscope to perform URS of the dilated ureters. However, it was only after Drs. Shepherd and Ritchey published their respective papers on pediatric URS in 1988 that this technique gained widespread acceptance by pediatric urologists."

*Reasoning*: The introduction provides a rationale for the review, including the historical context of ureteroscopy in pediatric patients.

*Response*: [Yes]

P4. Introduction / Objectives: Provide an explicit statement of questions being addressed with reference to participants, interventions, comparisons, outcomes, and study design (PICOS).

*Quote*: "The purpose of this study is to determine whether the safety and efficacy of URS now warrant it being considered the standard of care and the first line of therapy in the management of pediatric urolithiasis."

P5. Methods / Protocol and registration: Indicate if a review protocol exists, if and where it can be accessed (e.g., Web address), and, if available, provide registration information including registration number.

P7. Methods / Information sources: Describe all information sources (e.g., databases with dates of coverage, contact with study authors to identify additional studies) in the search and date last searched.

*Quote*: "A systematic review of articles written about ureteroscopy (URS) in the contemporary urological literature (19902009) on PubMed was undertaken."

AMSTAR:

A1. Was an 'a priori' design provided? The research question and inclusion criteria should be established before the conduct of the review.

*Quote*: "The purpose of this study is to determine whether the safety and efficacy of URS now warrant it being considered the standard of care and the first line of therapy in the management of pediatric urolithiasis."

*Reasoning*: The research question is clearly stated in the introduction of the article.

*Response*: [Yes]

A2. Was there duplicate study selection and data extraction? There should be at least two independent data extractors and a consensus procedure for disagreements should be in place.

*Quote*: "A systematic review of articles written about ureteroscopy (URS) in the contemporary urological literature (19902009) on PubMed was undertaken."

*Reasoning*: The authors conducted a systematic review of articles on PubMed, but it is not explicitly stated if there were at least two independent data extractors and a consensus procedure for disagreements.

*Response*: [NA]

A3. Was a comprehensive literature search performed? At least two electronic sources should be searched. The report must include years and databases used (e.g., Central, EMBASE, and MEDLINE). Key words and/or MESH terms must be stated and where feasible the search strategy should be provided. All searches should be supplemented by consulting current contents, reviews, textbooks, specialized registers, or experts in the particular field of study, and by reviewing the references in the studies found.

*Quote*: "A systematic review of articles written about ureteroscopy (URS) in the contemporary urological literature (19902009) on PubMed was undertaken."

*Reasoning*: The authors conducted a systematic review of articles on PubMed, but it is not explicitly stated if they searched other electronic sources or supplemented the search with other strategies.

*Response*: [No]

A4. Was the status of publication (i.e. grey literature) used as an inclusion criterion? The authors should state that they searched for reports regardless of their publication type. The authors should state whether or not they excluded any reports (from the systematic review), based on their publication status, language etc.

*Quote*: "The success rates and complications of pediatric ureteroscopic procedures were abstracted from the identified publications and the results were tabulated and compared with the success rates of shockwave lithotripsy."

*Reasoning*: The authors did not explicitly state if they searched for grey literature or if they excluded any reports based on their publication status.

*Response*: [No]

A5. Was a list of studies (included and excluded) provided? A list of included and excluded studies should be provided.

*Quote*: "A total of 27 papers that met the inclusion criteria for this review were identified and the data were abstracted."

*Reasoning*: The authors identified and abstracted data from 27 papers, but it is not explicitly stated if they provided a list of included and excluded studies.

*Response*: [NA]

A6. Were the characteristics of the included studies provided? In an aggregated form such as a table, data from the original studies should be provided on the participants, interventions and outcomes. The ranges of characteristics in all the studies analyzed e.g., age, race, sex, relevant socioeconomic data, disease status, duration, severity, or other diseases should be reported.

*Quote*: "Over the past 20 years, the results of 832 pediatric patients (mean age, 9.4 years) managed with URS to treat stones have been published in the urological literature."

*Reasoning*: The authors provided the mean age of the patients, but it is not explicitly stated if they reported the ranges of characteristics of the included studies.

*Response*: [NA]

A7. Was the scientific quality of the included studies assessed and documented? 'A priori' methods of assessment should be provided (e.g., for effectiveness studies if the author(s) chose to include only randomized, double-blind, placebo controlled studies, or allocation concealment as inclusion criteria); for other types of studies alternative items will be relevant.

*Quote*: "The success rate of URS is 93.4% (compared with 80.3% for ESWL). The complication rate associated with the URS procedures is 5.9% (compared with 8.4% for ESWL)."

*Reasoning*: The authors compared the success rate and complication rate of URS and ESWL, but it is not explicitly stated if they assessed and documented the scientific quality of the included studies.

*Response*: [No]

A8. Was the scientific quality of the included studies used appropriately in formulating conclusions? The results of the methodological rigor and scientific quality should be considered in the analysis and the conclusions of the review, and explicitly stated in formulating recommendations.

*Quote*: "In this systematic review of the literature, URS is shown to be safer and more efficacious than ESWL in the management of pediatric urolithiasis."

*Reasoning*: The authors concluded that URS is safer and more efficacious than ESWL in the management of pediatric urolithiasis, but it is not explicitly stated if they considered the results of the methodological rigor and scientific quality of the included studies in formulating their conclusions.

*Response*: [No]

A9. Were the methods used to combine the findings of studies appropriate? For the pooled results, a test should be done to ensure the studies were combinable, to assess their homogeneity (i.e., Chi-squared test for homogeneity, I2 ). If heterogeneity exists a random effects model should be used and/or the clinical appropriateness of combining should be taken into consideration (i.e., is it sensible to combine?).

*Quote*: "The success rate of URS is 93.4% (compared with 80.3% for ESWL). The complication rate associated with the URS procedures is 5.9% (compared with 8.4% for ESWL)."

*Reasoning*: The authors compared the success rate and complication rate of URS and ESWL, but it is not explicitly stated if they assessed the homogeneity of the studies or used appropriate methods to combine the findings.

*Response*: [No]

A10. Was the likelihood of publication bias assessed? An assessment of publication bias should include a combination of graphical aids (e.g., funnel plot, other available tests) and/or statistical tests (e.g., Egger regression test, Hedges-Olken).

*Quote*: "The success rate of URS is 93.4% (compared with 80.3% for ESWL). The complication rate associated with the URS procedures is 5.9% (compared with 8.4% for ESWL)."

*Reasoning*: The authors compared the success rate and complication rate of URS and ESWL, but it is not explicitly stated if they assessed the likelihood of publication bias.

*Response*: [No]

A11. Was the conflict of interest included? Potential sources of support should be clearly acknowledged in both the systematic review and the included studies.

*Quote*: "For correspondence: Dr. Pramod P. Reddy, 3333 Burnet Ave., Surgical Services, Division of Pediatric Urology (MC5037), Cincinnati Childrens Hospital Medical Center, Cincinnati, OH 45229, USA. E-mail: pramod.reddy@cchmc.org"

*Reasoning*: The authors provided their contact information, but it is not explicitly stated if they acknowledged potential sources of support.

*Response*: [NA]

PRISMA:

P1. Title: Identify the report as a systematic review, meta-analysis, or both.

*Quote*: "Ureteroscopy: The standard of care in the management of upper tract urolithiasis in children"

*Reasoning*: The title of the article suggests that it is a review article, but it is not explicitly stated if it is a systematic review or meta-analysis.

*Response*: [No]

P2. Abstract / Structured summary: Provide a structured summary including, as applicable: background; objectives; data sources; study eligibility criteria, participants, and interventions; study appraisal and synthesis methods; results; limitations; conclusions and implications of key findings; systematic review registration number.

*Quote*: "Abstract Objectives: Advances in technology and the continued evolution in the design of ureteroscopes now permit a primary endoscopic approach to the upper urinary tract of pediatric patients on a routine basis to treat a diverse group of conditions that include urolithiasis, hematuria and strictures. The purpose of this review article is to demonstrate that ureteroscopic lithotripsy is now to be considered the standard of care in the management of upper tract urolithiasis in the pediatric patient, replacing shockwave lithotripsy (ESWL) as the first line of therapy. Additionally, the article will discuss the available endoscopic equipment and the lessons learned over the years to optimize the success of these procedures in children."

*Reasoning*: The abstract provides a structured summary of the article, including the background, objectives, data sources, study eligibility criteria, participants, interventions, and results.

*Response*: [Yes]

P3. Introduction / Rationale: Describe the rationale for the review in the context of what is already known.

*Quote*: "The earliest documented instance of an ureteroscopic procedure was interestingly performed in a pediatric patient by Drs. Young and McKay in 1929 on a 2-week-old baby with posterior urethral valves. They used a pediatric cystoscope to perform URS of the dilated ureters. However, it was only after Drs. Shepherd and Ritchey published their respective papers on pediatric URS in 1988 that this technique gained widespread acceptance by pediatric urologists."

*Reasoning*: The introduction provides a rationale for the review, including the historical context of ureteroscopy in pediatric patients.

*Response*: [Yes]

P4. Introduction / Objectives: Provide an explicit statement of questions being addressed with reference to participants, interventions, comparisons, outcomes, and study design (PICOS).

*Quote*: "The purpose of this study is to determine whether the safety and efficacy of URS now warrant it being considered the standard of care and the first line of therapy in the management of pediatric urolithiasis."

*Reasoning*: The objectives of the study are explicitly stated in the introduction.

*Response*: [Yes]

P5. Methods / Protocol and registration: Indicate if a review protocol exists, if and where it can be accessed (e.g., Web address), and, if available, provide registration information including registration number.

*Quote*: "Not applicable."

*Reasoning*: The article does not mention if a review protocol exists or if it is registered.

*Response*: [No]

P6. Methods / Eligibility criteria: Specify study characteristics (e.g., PICOS, length of follow-up) and report characteristics (e.g., years considered, language, publication status) used as criteria for eligibility, giving rationale.

*Quote*: "A systematic review of articles written about ureteroscopy (URS) in the contemporary urological literature (19902009) on PubMed was undertaken."

*Reasoning*: The methods section specifies the study characteristics and report characteristics used as criteria for eligibility, but it does not provide a rationale for the eligibility criteria.

*Response*: [NA]

P7. Methods / Information sources: Describe all information sources (e.g., databases with dates of coverage, contact with study authors to identify additional studies) in the search and date last searched.

*Quote*: "A systematic review of articles written about ureteroscopy (URS) in the contemporary urological literature (19902009) on PubMed was undertaken."

*Reasoning*: The methods section specifies the information sources used in the search, but it does not provide the dates of coverage or the date last searched.

*Response*: [No]

P8. Methods / Search: Present full electronic search strategy for at least one database, including any limits used, such that it could be repeated.

*Quote*: "Not applicable."

*Reasoning*: The article does not provide the full electronic search strategy for at least one database.

*Response*: [No]

P9. Methods / Study selection: State the process for selecting studies (i.e., screening, eligibility, included in systematic review, and, if applicable, included in the meta-analysis).

*Quote*: "A systematic review of articles written about ureteroscopy (URS) in the contemporary urological literature (19902009) on PubMed was undertaken."

*Reasoning*: The methods section states the process for selecting studies, but it does not provide details on the screening, eligibility, and inclusion process.

*Response*: [No]

P10. Methods / Data collection process: Describe method of data extraction from reports (e.g., piloted forms, independently, in duplicate) and any processes for obtaining and confirming data from investigators.

*Quote*: "Not applicable."

*Reasoning*: The article does not provide information on the data collection process.

*Response*: [No]

P11. Methods / Data items: List and define all variables for which data were sought (e.g., PICOS, funding sources) and any assumptions and simplifications made.

*Quote*: "Not applicable."

*Reasoning*: The article does not provide information on the data items sought.

*Response*: [No]

P12. Methods / Risk of bias in individual studies: Describe methods used for assessing risk of bias of individual studies (including specification of whether this was done at the study or outcome level), and how this information is to be used in any data synthesis.

*Quote*: "Not applicable."

*Reasoning*: The article does not provide information on the risk of bias in individual studies.

*Response*: [No]

P13. Methods / Summary measures: State the principal summary measures (e.g., risk ratio, difference in means).

*Quote*: "The success rate of URS is 93.4% (compared with 80.3% for ESWL). The complication rate associated with the URS procedures is 5.9% (compared with 8.4% for ESWL)."

*Reasoning*: The methods section states the principal summary measures.

*Response*: [Yes]

P14. Methods / Synthesis of results: Describe the methods of handling data and combining results of studies, if done, including measures of consistency (e.g., I2) for each meta-analysis.

*Quote*: "Not applicable."

*Reasoning*: The article does not provide information on the synthesis of results.

*Response*: [No]

P15. Methods / Risk of bias across studies: Specify any assessment of risk of bias that may affect the cumulative evidence (e.g., publication bias, selective reporting within studies).

*Quote*: "Not applicable."

*Reasoning*: The article does not provide information on the risk of bias across studies.

*Response*: [No]

P16. Methods / Additional analyses: Describe methods of additional analyses (e.g., sensitivity or subgroup analyses, meta-regression), if done, indicating which were pre-specified.

*Quote*: "Not applicable."

*Reasoning*: The article does not provide information on additional analyses.

*Response*: [No]

P17. Results / Study selection: Give numbers of studies screened, assessed for eligibility, and included in the review, with reasons for exclusions at each stage, ideally with a flow diagram.

*Quote*: "A total of 27 papers that met the inclusion criteria for this review were identified and the data were abstracted."

*Reasoning*: The results section provides the number of papers included in the review, but it does not provide the number of studies screened, assessed for eligibility, or excluded.

*Response*: [No]

P18. Results / Study characteristics: For each study, present characteristics for which data were extracted (e.g., study size, PICOS, follow-up period) and provide the citations.

*Quote*: "Over the past 20 years, the results of 832 pediatric patients (mean age, 9.4 years) managed with URS to treat stones have been published in the urological literature."

*Reasoning*: The results section provides the characteristics of the patients included in the review, but it does not provide the characteristics of each study.

*Response*: [No]

P19. Results / Risk of bias within studies: Present data on risk of bias of each study and, if available, any outcome level assessment (see item P12).

*Quote*: "Not applicable."

*Reasoning*: The article does not provide information on the risk of bias within studies.

*Response*: [No]

P20. Results / Results of individual studies: For all outcomes considered (benefits or harms), present, for each study: (a) simple summary data for each intervention group (b) effect estimates and confidence intervals, ideally with a forest plot.

*Quote*: "The success rate of URS is 93.4% (compared with 80.3% for ESWL). The complication rate associated with the URS procedures is 5.9% (compared with 8.4% for ESWL)."

*Reasoning*: The results section provides the simple summary data for each intervention group, but it does not provide the effect estimates and confidence intervals.

*Response*: [No]

P21. Results / Synthesis of results: Present results of each meta-analysis done, including confidence intervals and measures of consistency.

*Quote*: "Not applicable."

*Reasoning*: The article does not provide information on the synthesis of results.

*Response*: [No]

P22. Results / Risk of bias across studies: Present results of any assessment of risk of bias that may affect the cumulative evidence (e.g., publication bias, selective reporting within studies).

*Quote*: "Not applicable."

*Reasoning*: The article does not provide information on the risk of bias across studies.

*Response*: [No]

P23. Results / Additional analysis: Give results of additional analyses, if done (e.g., sensitivity or subgroup analyses, meta-regression).

*Quote*: "Not applicable."

*Reasoning*: The article does not provide information on additional analyses.

*Response*: [No]

P24. Discussion / Summary of evidence: Summarize the main findings including the strength of evidence for each main outcome; consider their relevance to key groups (e.g., healthcare providers, users, and policy makers).

*Quote*: "In this systematic review of the literature, URS is shown to be safer and more efficacious than ESWL in the management of pediatric urolithiasis."

*Reasoning*: The discussion section summarizes the main findings and the relevance of the findings to key groups.

*Response*: [Yes]

P25. Discussion / Limitations: Discuss limitations at study and outcome level (e.g., risk of bias), and at review-level (e.g., incomplete retrieval of identified research, reporting bias).

*Quote*: "The success rate of URS is 93.4% (compared with 80.3% for ESWL). The complication rate associated with the URS procedures is 5.9% (compared with 8.4% for ESWL)."

*Reasoning*: The discussion section does not explicitly discuss the limitations of the review.

*Response*: [No]

P26. Discussion / Conclusions: Provide a general interpretation of the results in the context of other evidence, and implications for future research.

*Quote*: "In this systematic review of the literature, URS is shown to be safer and more efficacious than ESWL in the management of pediatric urolithiasis."

*Reasoning*: The discussion section provides a general interpretation of the results and implications for future research.

*Response*: [Yes]

P27. Funding: Describe sources of funding for the systematic review and other support (e.g., supply of data); role of funders for the systematic review.

*Quote*: "Not applicable."

*Reasoning*: The article does not provide information on the sources of funding for the systematic review.

*Response*: [No]

llm_message:
AMSTAR:

A1. Was an 'a priori' design provided? The research question and inclusion criteria should be established before the conduct of the review. Note: Need to refer to a protocol, ethics approval, or pre-determined/a priori published research objectives to score a yes.

* Quote: "We undertook a systematic review of all studies published over a period of 20 years (19942014) that assessed functional outcomes for OD and/or LD procedures for HD."
* Reasoning: The research question and inclusion criteria are not explicitly stated in the text, but the authors mention that they conducted a systematic review of studies published over a period of 20 years that assessed functional outcomes for OD and/or LD procedures for HD.
* Response: [No]

A2. Was there duplicate study selection and data extraction? There should be at least two independent data extractors and a consensus procedure for disagreements should be in place. Note: 2 people do study selection, 2 people do data extraction, consensus process or one person checks the others work.

* Quote: "We undertook a systematic review of all studies published over a period of 20 years (19942014) that assessed functional outcomes for OD and/or LD procedures for HD."
* Reasoning: The text does not provide information on whether study selection and data extraction were performed independently by two or more individuals.
* Response: [No]

A3. Was a comprehensive literature search performed? At least two electronic sources should be searched. The report must include years and databases used (e.g., Central, EMBASE, and MEDLINE). Key words and/or MESH terms must be stated and where feasible the search strategy should be provided. All searches should be supplemented by consulting current contents, reviews, textbooks, specialized registers, or experts in the particular field of study, and by reviewing the references in the studies found. Note: If at least 2 sources + one supplementary strategy used, select yes (Cochrane register/Central counts as 2 sources; a grey literature search counts as supplementary).

* Quote: "A systematic PubMed search was performed to identify publications that analyzed outcomes for LD or OD pull-through procedures for HD. All studies between January 1994 and December 2014 were included in the search, as the first LD pull-through was described in 1994. Combinations of the key words Hirschsprung disease, Duhamel, pull-through, lapa-roscopic, minimally invasive and open were used."
* Reasoning: The authors mention that they conducted a systematic search of publications in PubMed between January 1994 and December 2014 using specific keywords. However, they do not mention whether they searched additional electronic sources or used any supplementary strategies.
* Response: [No]

A4. Was the status of publication (i.e. grey literature) used as an inclusion criterion? The authors should state that they searched for reports regardless of their publication type. The authors should state whether or not they excluded any reports (from the systematic review), based on their publication status, language etc. Note: If review indicates that there was a search for grey literature or unpublished literature, indicate yes. SIGLE database, dissertations, conference proceedings, and trial registries are all considered grey for this purpose. If searching a source that contains both grey and non-grey, must specify that they were searching for grey/unpublished lit.

* Quote: "All studies assessing functional outcome for OD and/or LD procedures for HD were analyzed for eligibility, including randomized control trials and observational studies. Exclusion criteria included patients with total colonic aganglionosis, follow-up of less than 6 months, cohorts smaller than 10 patients, full articles not written in English, and nonpeer-reviewed articles. Studies with insufficient operation details or those that did not differentiate between the two approaches were also excluded."
* Reasoning: The authors mention that they excluded studies based on language and peer-review status, but they do not mention whether they searched for or included grey literature.
* Response: [No]

A5. Was a list of studies (included and excluded) provided? A list of included and excluded studies should be provided. Note: Acceptable if the excluded studies are referenced. If there is an electronic link to the list but the link is dead, select no.

* Quote: "Eleven articles met our strict inclusion criteria and were included in the meta-analysis."
* Reasoning: The authors mention that they included 11 articles in their meta-analysis, but they do not provide a list of included or excluded studies.
* Response: [No]

A6. Were the characteristics of the included studies provided? In an aggregated form such as a table, data from the original studies should be provided on the participants, interventions and outcomes. The ranges of characteristics in all the studies analyzed e.g., age, race, sex, relevant socioeconomic data, disease status, duration, severity, or other diseases should be reported. Note: Acceptable if not in table format as long as they are described as above.

* Quote: "Four hundred fifty-six patients with HD were included in this review (range, 20--76 patients per study). Of these, 253 patients underwent an OD procedure, and 203 underwent a LD procedure. The median age at surgery in the open group was 6.9 months (range, 4--42 months), compared with 11.3 months (range, 3.1--17.2 months) in the laparoscopic group. Median follow-up in the open group was 64.8 months (range, 14--87.8 months) compared with 61.2 months in the laparoscopic group (range, 39.5--80 months)."
* Reasoning: The authors provide some characteristics of the included studies, including the number of patients, age at surgery, and follow-up duration. However, they do not provide information on the interventions or outcomes.
* Response: [No]

A7. Was the scientific quality of the included studies assessed and documented? 'A priori' methods of assessment should be provided (e.g., for effectiveness studies if the author(s) chose to include only randomized, double-blind, placebo controlled studies, or allocation concealment as inclusion criteria); for other types of studies alternative items will be relevant. Note: Can include use of a quality scoring tool or checklist, e.g., Jadad scale, risk of bias, sensitivity analysis, etc., or a description of quality items, with some kind of result for EACH study (low or high is fine, as long as it is clear which studies scored low and which scored high; a summary score/range for all studies is not acceptable).

* Quote: "The risk of bias was assessed and summarized for the 11 articles included in the meta-analysis."
* Reasoning: The authors mention that they assessed the risk of bias for the included studies, but they do not provide information on the methods of assessment or the results for each study.
* Response: [No]

A8. Was the scientific quality of the included studies used appropriately in formulating conclusions? The results of the methodological rigor and scientific quality should be considered in the analysis and the conclusions of the review, and explicitly stated in formulating recommendations. Note: Might say something such as the results should be interpreted with caution due to poor quality of included studies. Cannot score yes for this question if scored no for question A7.

* Quote: "Our meta-analysis convincingly demonstrates the superiority of LD over OD pull-through for HD."
* Reasoning: The authors conclude that laparoscopic Duhamel (LD) is superior to open Duhamel (OD) for Hirschsprung's disease (HD), but they do not mention or consider the scientific quality of the included studies in their conclusions.
* Response: [No]

A9. Were the methods used to combine the findings of studies appropriate? For the pooled results, a test should be done to ensure the studies were combinable, to assess their homogeneity (i.e., Chi-squared test for homogeneity, I2 ). If heterogeneity exists a random effects model should be used and/or the clinical appropriateness of combining should be taken into consideration (i.e., is it sensible to combine?). Note: Indicate yes if they mention or describe heterogeneity, i.e., if they explain that they cannot pool because of heterogeneity/variability between interventions.

* Quote: "A cumulative meta-analysis was then performed, to compare the incidence of each outcome in patients who underwent the OD procedure with those who underwent the LD procedure. Odds ratios (ORs) were calculated for dichotomous variables using the MantelHaenszel method, and mean differences (MDs) were measured for continuous variables using the inverse variance method. A random-effects analysis model was used for all outcomes, as it acknowledges a degree of heterogeneity between studies that makes it well suited for meta-analysis in pediatric surgery."
* Reasoning: The authors mention that they used a random-effects analysis model and calculated odds ratios and mean differences for the pooled results, but they do not provide information on the homogeneity of the studies or the clinical appropriateness of combining the findings.
* Response: [No]

A10. Was the likelihood of publication bias assessed? An assessment of publication bias should include a combination of graphical aids (e.g., funnel plot, other available tests) and/or statistical tests (e.g., Egger regression test, Hedges-Olken). Note: If no test values or funnel plot included, score no. Score yes if mentions that publication bias could not be assessed because there were fewer than 10 included studies.

* Quote: "Statistical heterogeneity was assessed using I2 ."
* Reasoning: The authors mention that they assessed statistical heterogeneity using I2, but they do not mention whether they assessed publication bias.
* Response: [No]

A11. Was the conflict of interest included? Potential sources of support should be clearly acknowledged in both the systematic review and the included studies. Note: To get a yes, must indicate source of funding or support for the systematic review AND for each of the included studies.

* Quote: "Department of Paediatric Surgery, Birmingham Childrens Hospital, Birmingham, United Kingdom."
* Reasoning: The authors do not mention the source of funding or support for the systematic review or the included studies.
* Response: [No]

PRISMA:

P1. Title: Identify the report as a systematic review, meta-analysis, or both.

* Quote: "Laparoscopic Duhamel Procedure for Hirschsprungs Disease: Systematic Review and Meta-analysis"
* Reasoning: The authors identify the report as a systematic review and meta-analysis in the title.
* Response: [Yes]

P2. Abstract / Structured summary: Provide a structured summary including, as applicable: background; objectives; data sources; study eligibility criteria, participants, and interventions; study appraisal and synthesis methods; results; limitations; conclusions and implications of key findings; systematic review registration number.

* Quote: "Abstract: Introduction: Since its introduction in 1956, the Duhamel procedure has been and remains one of the most widely performed for Hirschsprungs disease (HD). The most significant modification to this procedure has been the incorporation of laparoscopy, while the original principles of the method have been retained. This study compared long-term outcomes for open Duhamel (OD) and laparoscopic Duhamel (LD) procedures for HD, to identify any added advantage of the laparoscopic technique. Materials and Methods: We undertook a systematic review of all studies published over a period of 20 years (1994--2014) that assessed functional outcomes for OD and/or LD procedures for HD. Odds ratios were calculated for dichotomous variables, and mean difference values were calculated for continuous variables. Results: From 11 articles 456 patients were included (253 OD, 203 LD), with no significant difference in age at surgery and length of follow-up (P > .05). The open group had a significantly greater incidence of soiling/incontinence (11% versus 4%; P = .02) and further surgery (25% versus 14%; P = .005), longer hospital stay (9.79 versus 7.3 days; P < .00001), and time to oral feed (4.05 versus 3.27 days; P < .00001). Operative time was significantly longer in the laparoscopic group (3.83 versus 4.09 hours; P = .004). There was no significant difference in incidence of enterocolitis (15% versus 10%; P = .14) and constipation (23% versus 30%; P = .12). Conclusions: Our meta-analysis convincingly demonstrates the superiority of LD over OD pull-through for HD. Prospective, randomized control trials are required to overcome limitations in the current literature."
* Reasoning: The authors provide a structured summary including the background, objectives, data sources, study eligibility criteria, participants, interventions, study appraisal and synthesis methods, results, limitations, conclusions, and implications of key findings.
* Response: [Yes]

P3. Introduction / Rationale: Describe the rationale for the review in the context of what is already known.

* Quote: "Introduction: Since its introduction in 1956, the Duhamel procedure has been and remains one of the most widely performed for Hirschsprungs disease (HD). The most significant modification to this procedure has been the incorporation of laparoscopy, while the original principles of the method have been retained. This study compared long-term outcomes for open Duhamel (OD) and laparoscopic Duhamel (LD) procedures for HD, to identify any added advantage of the laparoscopic technique."
* Reasoning: The authors describe the rationale for the review in the context of what is already known.
* Response: [Yes]

P4. Introduction / Objectives: Provide an explicit statement of questions being addressed with reference to participants, interventions, comparisons, outcomes, and study design (PICOS).

* Quote: "Introduction: Since its introduction in 1956, the Duhamel procedure has been and remains one of the most widely performed for Hirschsprungs disease (HD). The most significant modification to this procedure has been the incorporation of laparoscopy, while the original principles of the method have been retained. This study compared long-term outcomes for open Duhamel (OD) and laparoscopic Duhamel (LD) procedures for HD, to identify any added advantage of the laparoscopic technique."
* Reasoning: The authors do not provide an explicit statement of questions being addressed with reference to participants, interventions, comparisons, outcomes, and study design (PICOS).
* Response: [No]

P5. Methods / Protocol and registration: Indicate if a review protocol exists, if and where it can be accessed (e.g., Web address), and, if available, provide registration information including registration number.

* Quote: Not applicable.
* Reasoning: The authors do not mention whether a review protocol exists or whether the review is registered.
* Response: [NA]

P6. Methods / Eligibility criteria: Specify study characteristics (e.g., PICOS, length of follow-up) and report characteristics (e.g., years considered, language, publication status) used as criteria for eligibility, giving rationale.

* Quote: "Materials and Methods: We undertook a systematic review of all studies published over a period of 20 years (1994--2014) that assessed functional outcomes for OD and/or LD procedures for HD. Exclusion criteria included patients with total colonic aganglionosis, follow-up of less than 6 months, cohorts smaller than 10 patients, full articles not written in English, and non--peer-reviewed articles. Studies with insufficient operation details or those that did not differentiate between the two approaches were also excluded."
* Reasoning: The authors specify study characteristics (PICOS) and report characteristics used as criteria for eligibility, giving rationale.
* Response: [Yes]

P7. Methods / Information sources: Describe all information sources (e.g., databases with dates of coverage, contact with study authors to identify additional studies) in the search and date last searched.

* Quote: "Materials and Methods: We undertook a systematic review of all studies published over a period of 20 years (1994--2014) that assessed functional outcomes for OD and/or LD procedures for HD. A systematic PubMed search was performed to identify publications that analyzed outcomes for LD or OD pull-through procedures for HD. Combinations of the key words Hirschsprung disease, Duhamel, pull-through, lapa-roscopic, minimally invasive and open were used."
* Reasoning: The authors describe the information sources used in the search and the date last searched.
* Response: [Yes]

P8. Methods / Search: Present full electronic search strategy for at least one database, including any limits used, such that it could be repeated.

* Quote: Not applicable.

original_llm_message:
AMSTAR:

A1. Was an 'a priori' design provided? The research question and inclusion criteria should be established before the conduct of the review. Note: Need to refer to a protocol, ethics approval, or pre-determined/a priori published research objectives to score a yes.

* Quote: "We undertook a systematic review of all studies published over a period of 20 years (19942014) that assessed functional outcomes for OD and/or LD procedures for HD."
* Reasoning: The research question and inclusion criteria are not explicitly stated in the text, but the authors mention that they conducted a systematic review of studies published over a period of 20 years that assessed functional outcomes for OD and/or LD procedures for HD.
* Response: [No]

A2. Was there duplicate study selection and data extraction? There should be at least two independent data extractors and a consensus procedure for disagreements should be in place. Note: 2 people do study selection, 2 people do data extraction, consensus process or one person checks the others work.

* Quote: "We undertook a systematic review of all studies published over a period of 20 years (19942014) that assessed functional outcomes for OD and/or LD procedures for HD."
* Reasoning: The text does not provide information on whether study selection and data extraction were performed independently by two or more individuals.
* Response: [No]

A3. Was a comprehensive literature search performed? At least two electronic sources should be searched. The report must include years and databases used (e.g., Central, EMBASE, and MEDLINE). Key words and/or MESH terms must be stated and where feasible the search strategy should be provided. All searches should be supplemented by consulting current contents, reviews, textbooks, specialized registers, or experts in the particular field of study, and by reviewing the references in the studies found. Note: If at least 2 sources + one supplementary strategy used, select yes (Cochrane register/Central counts as 2 sources; a grey literature search counts as supplementary).

* Quote: "A systematic PubMed search was performed to identify publications that analyzed outcomes for LD or OD pull-through procedures for HD. All studies between January 1994 and December 2014 were included in the search, as the first LD pull-through was described in 1994. Combinations of the key words Hirschsprung disease, Duhamel, pull-through, lapa-roscopic, minimally invasive and open were used."
* Reasoning: The authors mention that they conducted a systematic search of publications in PubMed between January 1994 and December 2014 using specific keywords. However, they do not mention whether they searched additional electronic sources or used any supplementary strategies.
* Response: [No]

A4. Was the status of publication (i.e. grey literature) used as an inclusion criterion? The authors should state that they searched for reports regardless of their publication type. The authors should state whether or not they excluded any reports (from the systematic review), based on their publication status, language etc. Note: If review indicates that there was a search for grey literature or unpublished literature, indicate yes. SIGLE database, dissertations, conference proceedings, and trial registries are all considered grey for this purpose. If searching a source that contains both grey and non-grey, must specify that they were searching for grey/unpublished lit.

* Quote: "All studies assessing functional outcome for OD and/or LD procedures for HD were analyzed for eligibility, including randomized control trials and observational studies. Exclusion criteria included patients with total colonic aganglionosis, follow-up of less than 6 months, cohorts smaller than 10 patients, full articles not written in English, and nonpeer-reviewed articles. Studies with insufficient operation details or those that did not differentiate between the two approaches were also excluded."
* Reasoning: The authors mention that they excluded studies based on language and peer-review status, but they do not mention whether they searched for or included grey literature.
* Response: [No]

A5. Was a list of studies (included and excluded) provided? A list of included and excluded studies should be provided. Note: Acceptable if the excluded studies are referenced. If there is an electronic link to the list but the link is dead, select no.

* Quote: "Eleven articles met our strict inclusion criteria and were included in the meta-analysis."
* Reasoning: The authors mention that they included 11 articles in their meta-analysis, but they do not provide a list of included or excluded studies.
* Response: [No]

A6. Were the characteristics of the included studies provided? In an aggregated form such as a table, data from the original studies should be provided on the participants, interventions and outcomes. The ranges of characteristics in all the studies analyzed e.g., age, race, sex, relevant socioeconomic data, disease status, duration, severity, or other diseases should be reported. Note: Acceptable if not in table format as long as they are described as above.

* Quote: "Four hundred fifty-six patients with HD were included in this review (range, 20--76 patients per study). Of these, 253 patients underwent an OD procedure, and 203 underwent a LD procedure. The median age at surgery in the open group was 6.9 months (range, 4--42 months), compared with 11.3 months (range, 3.1--17.2 months) in the laparoscopic group. Median follow-up in the open group was 64.8 months (range, 14--87.8 months) compared with 61.2 months in the laparoscopic group (range, 39.5--80 months)."
* Reasoning: The authors provide some characteristics of the included studies, including the number of patients, age at surgery, and follow-up duration. However, they do not provide information on the interventions or outcomes.
* Response: [No]

A7. Was the scientific quality of the included studies assessed and documented? 'A priori' methods of assessment should be provided (e.g., for effectiveness studies if the author(s) chose to include only randomized, double-blind, placebo controlled studies, or allocation concealment as inclusion criteria); for other types of studies alternative items will be relevant. Note: Can include use of a quality scoring tool or checklist, e.g., Jadad scale, risk of bias, sensitivity analysis, etc., or a description of quality items, with some kind of result for EACH study (low or high is fine, as long as it is clear which studies scored low and which scored high; a summary score/range for all studies is not acceptable).

* Quote: "The risk of bias was assessed and summarized for the 11 articles included in the meta-analysis."
* Reasoning: The authors mention that they assessed the risk of bias for the included studies, but they do not provide information on the methods of assessment or the results for each study.
* Response: [No]

A8. Was the scientific quality of the included studies used appropriately in formulating conclusions? The results of the methodological rigor and scientific quality should be considered in the analysis and the conclusions of the review, and explicitly stated in formulating recommendations. Note: Might say something such as the results should be interpreted with caution due to poor quality of included studies. Cannot score yes for this question if scored no for question A7.

* Quote: "Our meta-analysis convincingly demonstrates the superiority of LD over OD pull-through for HD."
* Reasoning: The authors conclude that laparoscopic Duhamel (LD) is superior to open Duhamel (OD) for Hirschsprung's disease (HD), but they do not mention or consider the scientific quality of the included studies in their conclusions.
* Response: [No]

A9. Were the methods used to combine the findings of studies appropriate? For the pooled results, a test should be done to ensure the studies were combinable, to assess their homogeneity (i.e., Chi-squared test for homogeneity, I2 ). If heterogeneity exists a random effects model should be used and/or the clinical appropriateness of combining should be taken into consideration (i.e., is it sensible to combine?). Note: Indicate yes if they mention or describe heterogeneity, i.e., if they explain that they cannot pool because of heterogeneity/variability between interventions.

* Quote: "A cumulative meta-analysis was then performed, to compare the incidence of each outcome in patients who underwent the OD procedure with those who underwent the LD procedure. Odds ratios (ORs) were calculated for dichotomous variables using the MantelHaenszel method, and mean differences (MDs) were measured for continuous variables using the inverse variance method. A random-effects analysis model was used for all outcomes, as it acknowledges a degree of heterogeneity between studies that makes it well suited for meta-analysis in pediatric surgery."
* Reasoning: The authors mention that they used a random-effects analysis model and calculated odds ratios and mean differences for the pooled results, but they do not provide information on the homogeneity of the studies or the clinical appropriateness of combining the findings.
* Response: [No]

A10. Was the likelihood of publication bias assessed? An assessment of publication bias should include a combination of graphical aids (e.g., funnel plot, other available tests) and/or statistical tests (e.g., Egger regression test, Hedges-Olken). Note: If no test values or funnel plot included, score no. Score yes if mentions that publication bias could not be assessed because there were fewer than 10 included studies.

* Quote: "Statistical heterogeneity was assessed using I2 ."
* Reasoning: The authors mention that they assessed statistical heterogeneity using I2, but they do not mention whether they assessed publication bias.
* Response: [No]

A11. Was the conflict of interest included? Potential sources of support should be clearly acknowledged in both the systematic review and the included studies. Note: To get a yes, must indicate source of funding or support for the systematic review AND for each of the included studies.

* Quote: "Department of Paediatric Surgery, Birmingham Childrens Hospital, Birmingham, United Kingdom."
* Reasoning: The authors do not mention the source of funding or support for the systematic review or the included studies.
* Response: [No]

PRISMA:

P1. Title: Identify the report as a systematic review, meta-analysis, or both.

* Quote: "Laparoscopic Duhamel Procedure for Hirschsprungs Disease: Systematic Review and Meta-analysis"
* Reasoning: The authors identify the report as a systematic review and meta-analysis in the title.
* Response: [Yes]

P2. Abstract / Structured summary: Provide a structured summary including, as applicable: background; objectives; data sources; study eligibility criteria, participants, and interventions; study appraisal and synthesis methods; results; limitations; conclusions and implications of key findings; systematic review registration number.

* Quote: "Abstract: Introduction: Since its introduction in 1956, the Duhamel procedure has been and remains one of the most widely performed for Hirschsprungs disease (HD). The most significant modification to this procedure has been the incorporation of laparoscopy, while the original principles of the method have been retained. This study compared long-term outcomes for open Duhamel (OD) and laparoscopic Duhamel (LD) procedures for HD, to identify any added advantage of the laparoscopic technique. Materials and Methods: We undertook a systematic review of all studies published over a period of 20 years (1994--2014) that assessed functional outcomes for OD and/or LD procedures for HD. Odds ratios were calculated for dichotomous variables, and mean difference values were calculated for continuous variables. Results: From 11 articles 456 patients were included (253 OD, 203 LD), with no significant difference in age at surgery and length of follow-up (P > .05). The open group had a significantly greater incidence of soiling/incontinence (11% versus 4%; P = .02) and further surgery (25% versus 14%; P = .005), longer hospital stay (9.79 versus 7.3 days; P < .00001), and time to oral feed (4.05 versus 3.27 days; P < .00001). Operative time was significantly longer in the laparoscopic group (3.83 versus 4.09 hours; P = .004). There was no significant difference in incidence of enterocolitis (15% versus 10%; P = .14) and constipation (23% versus 30%; P = .12). Conclusions: Our meta-analysis convincingly demonstrates the superiority of LD over OD pull-through for HD. Prospective, randomized control trials are required to overcome limitations in the current literature."
* Reasoning: The authors provide a structured summary including the background, objectives, data sources, study eligibility criteria, participants, interventions, study appraisal and synthesis methods, results, limitations, conclusions, and implications of key findings.
* Response: [Yes]

P26. Discussion / Conclusions: Provide a general interpretation of the results in the context of other evidence, and implications for future research.

* Quote: "Conclusions: Our meta-analysis convincingly demonstrates the superiority of LD over OD pull-through for HD. Prospective, randomized control trials are required to overcome limitations in the current literature."
* Reasoning: The authors provide a general interpretation of the results in the context of other evidence and implications for future research.
* Response: [Yes]

P27. Funding: Describe sources of funding for the systematic review and other support (e.g., supply of data); role of funders for the systematic review.

* Quote: Not applicable.
* Reasoning: The authors do not mention the sources of funding for the systematic review or other support.
* Response: [NA]

llm_message:
AMSTAR:

A1. Was an 'a priori' design provided?
> "The research question and inclusion criteria should be established before the conduct of the review."
- The full text does not provide any information about an 'a priori' design.
> [No]

A2. Was there duplicate study selection and data extraction?
> "There should be at least two independent data extractors and a consensus procedure for disagreements should be in place."
- The full text does not provide any information about duplicate study selection and data extraction.
> [No]

A3. Was a comprehensive literature search performed?
> "At least two electronic sources should be searched. The report must include years and databases used (e.g., Central, EMBASE, and MEDLINE). Key words and/or MESH terms must be stated and where feasible the search strategy should be provided."
- The full text provides information about the literature search, including the databases used (MEDLINE, EMBASE, and CINAHL) and the keywords used. However, the full search strategy is not provided.
> [No]

A4. Was the status of publication (i.e. grey literature) used as an inclusion criterion?
> "The authors should state that they searched for reports regardless of their publication type. The authors should state whether or not they excluded any reports (from the systematic review), based on their publication status, language etc."
- The full text does not provide any information about the inclusion or exclusion of grey literature.
> [No]

A5. Was a list of studies (included and excluded) provided?
> "A list of included and excluded studies should be provided."
- The full text does not provide a list of included and excluded studies.
> [No]

A6. Were the characteristics of the included studies provided?
> "In an aggregated form such as a table, data from the original studies should be provided on the participants, interventions and outcomes."
- The full text provides a table with the characteristics of the included studies.
> [Yes]

A7. Was the scientific quality of the included studies assessed and documented?
> "'A priori' methods of assessment should be provided (e.g., for effectiveness studies if the author(s) chose to include only randomized, double-blind, placebo controlled studies, or allocation concealment as inclusion criteria); for other types of studies alternative items will be relevant."
- The full text does not provide any information about the assessment and documentation of the scientific quality of the included studies.
> [No]

A8. Was the scientific quality of the included studies used appropriately in formulating conclusions?
> "The results of the methodological rigor and scientific quality should be considered in the analysis and the conclusions of the review, and explicitly stated in formulating recommendations."
- The full text does not provide any information about the use of the scientific quality of the included studies in formulating conclusions.
> [No]

A9. Were the methods used to combine the findings of studies appropriate?
> "For the pooled results, a test should be done to ensure the studies were combinable, to assess their homogeneity (i.e., Chi-squared test for homogeneity, I2 ). If heterogeneity exists a random effects model should be used and/or the clinical appropriateness of combining should be taken into consideration (i.e., is it sensible to combine?)."
- This question is not applicable as the full text does not include a meta-analysis.
> [NA]

A10. Was the likelihood of publication bias assessed?
> "An assessment of publication bias should include a combination of graphical aids (e.g., funnel plot, other available tests) and/or statistical tests (e.g., Egger regression test, Hedges-Olken)."
- This question is not applicable as the full text does not include a meta-analysis.
> [NA]

A11. Was the conflict of interest included?
> "Potential sources of support should be clearly acknowledged in both the systematic review and the included studies."
- The full text does not provide any information about the conflict of interest.
> [No]

PRISMA:

P1. Title: Identify the report as a systematic review, meta-analysis, or both.
> "The objective of this study is to meta-analyse the published literature comparing outcomes after ONF and LNF for childhood GORD."
- The full text identifies the report as a meta-analysis.
> [Yes]

P2. Abstract / Structured summary: Provide a structured summary including, as applicable: background; objectives; data sources; study eligibility criteria, participants, and interventions; study appraisal and synthesis methods; results; limitations; conclusions and implications of key findings; systematic review registration number.
> The full text provides a structured abstract with the background, objectives, data sources, study eligibility criteria, participants, interventions, study appraisal and synthesis methods, results, and conclusions.
> [Yes]

P3. Introduction / Rationale: Describe the rationale for the review in the context of what is already known.
> The full text provides a rationale for the review in the context of what is already known.
> [Yes]

P4. Introduction / Objectives: Provide an explicit statement of questions being addressed with reference to participants, interventions, comparisons, outcomes, and study design (PICOS).
> The full text provides an explicit statement of questions being addressed with reference to participants, interventions, comparisons, outcomes, and study design.
> [Yes]

P5. Methods / Protocol and registration: Indicate if a review protocol exists, if and where it can be accessed (e.g., Web address), and, if available, provide registration information including registration number.
> The full text does not provide any information about a review protocol or registration.
> [No]

P6. Methods / Eligibility criteria: Specify study characteristics (e.g., PICOS, length of follow-up) and report characteristics (e.g., years considered, language, publication status) used as criteria for eligibility, giving rationale.
> The full text provides information about the eligibility criteria, including study characteristics and report characteristics.
> [Yes]
