* [NA]

P6. Methods / Eligibility criteria: Specify study characteristics (e.g., PICOS, length of follow-up) and report characteristics (e.g., years considered, language, publication status) used as criteria for eligibility, giving rationale.

* "Predetermined criteria for study inclusion consisted of 1) publication between 1990 and 2010, 2) focus on human subjects, 3) hypospadias as primary diagnosis, 4) exposure of patients to some form of hormonal stimulation preoperatively or postoperatively, 5) performance of surgical repair, 6) reporting of postoperative complications and 7) clinical research designation. All study types were included in the review. English language was not used as an eligibility criterion to avoid language bias." (Fulltext)
* The review specifies study characteristics and report characteristics used as criteria for eligibility, giving rationale.
* [Yes]

P7. Methods / Information sources: Describe all information sources (e.g., databases with dates of coverage, contact with study authors to identify additional studies) in the search and date last searched.

* "We conducted a comprehensive search of MEDLINE, Embase, CINAHL, SciELO, CENTRAL, Cochrane Data-base of Systematic Reviews and reference lists of prominent studies from 1990 to 2010. A gray literature search of conference abstracts was also performed." (Fulltext)
* The review describes all information sources in the search and date last searched.
* [Yes]

P8. Methods / Search: Present full electronic search strategy for at least one database, including any limits used, such that it could be repeated.

* "Not applicable" (Fulltext)
* The review does not provide the full electronic search strategy for at least one database, including any limits used.
* [NA]

P9. Methods / Study selection: State the process for selecting studies (i.e., screening, eligibility, included in systematic review, and, if applicable, included in the meta-analysis).

* "Title and abstract screening was conducted independently by 2 authors to select all citations that might contain comparisons of interest. Full text of each included article was obtained and data were abstracted independently by 2 authors. All screening results were reviewed for concordance and all discrepancies were resolved by consensus. Study selection was not blinded, as concealment has not been found to have a significant effect on the final results of systematic reviews." (Fulltext)
* The review states the process for selecting studies.
* [Yes]

P10. Methods / Data collection process: Describe method of data extraction from reports (e.g., piloted forms, independently, in duplicate) and any processes for obtaining and confirming data from investigators.

* "Data extraction was completed in duplicate and reviewed for accuracy and quality. When data for a particular study were unclear or missing from the article, we attempted to contact the authors. Unfortunately in some cases we were unable to obtain any additional information." (Fulltext)
* The review describes the method of data extraction from reports and any processes for obtaining and confirming data from investigators.
* [Yes]

P11. Methods / Data items: List and define all variables for which data were sought (e.g., PICOS, funding sources) and any assumptions and simplifications made.

* "Not applicable" (Fulltext)
* The review does not provide information on the variables for which data were sought, assumptions and simplifications made.
* [NA]

P12. Methods / Risk of bias in individual studies: Describe methods used for assessing risk of bias of individual studies (including specification of whether this was done at the study or outcome level), and how this information is to be used in any data synthesis.

* "Quality appraisal of the included studies was carried out by 2 independent reviewers using a quality assessment instrument adopted from Elyas et al, modified to fit the objectives of this study. All discrepancies were resolved through third-party review of the methodology. Study rating was determined by dividing the number of criteria met (indicated as Yes) by the total number of quality assurance criteria in the instrument (13), obtaining a percentage result. The data were then segregated into studies that met less than 25% of the quality criteria (very low quality), 25% to 49% (low quality), 50% to 74% (moderate quality) and more than 75% (high methodological quality)." (Fulltext)
* The review describes methods used for assessing risk of bias of individual studies and how this information is to be used in any data synthesis.
* [Yes]

P13. Methods / Summary measures: State the principal summary measures (e.g., risk ratio, difference in means).

* "Not applicable" (Fulltext)
* The review does not provide information on the principal summary measures.
* [NA]

P14. Methods / Synthesis of results: Describe the methods of handling data and combining results of studies, if done, including measures of consistency (e.g., I2) for each meta-analysis.

* "Attempts were made to compile and summarize the results providing clinically meaningful information and, as such, not all included studies are used in every table. Where appropriate, data were compiled using means, standard deviations, counts and percentages. Due to expected differences in observational designs, we planned a priori to use random effects models to account for between study heterogeneity for single group and comparative cohort studies. Heterogeneity between studies was tested using the Cochran chi-square Q test with a p value set at 0.1 and quantified using the I 2 statistic, which represents the percentage of total variation across included studies that is due to heterogeneity rather than chance. Publication bias was graphically assessed by constructing funnel plots depicting precision (standard error) plotted against the proportion of complications. The DerSimonian-Laird method was followed to estimate the pooled weighted complication proportion of the included studies. We used StatsDirect statistical software to calculate the pooled weighted proportions. For single group studies with subgroup analysis of PHS use and for comparative studies of PHS use we analyzed data with a random effects model using the Mantel-Haenszel method to calculate OR and 95% CI for complication as primary outcome measure. RevMan, version 5.1 (Cochrane IMS, Oxford, England) was used to calculate ORs. A p value of 0.05 was set for statistical significance." (Fulltext)
* The review describes the methods of handling data and combining results of studies, if done, including measures of consistency (e.g., I2) for each meta-analysis.
* [Yes]

P15. Methods / Risk of bias across studies: Specify any assessment of risk of bias that may affect the cumulative evidence (e.g., publication bias, selective reporting within studies).

* "Publication bias was graphically assessed by constructing funnel plots depicting precision (standard error) plotted against the proportion of complications." (Fulltext)
* The review specifies assessment of risk of bias that may affect the cumulative evidence.
* [Yes]

P16. Methods / Additional analyses: Describe methods of additional analyses (e.g., sensitivity or subgroup analyses, meta-regression), if done, indicating which were pre-specified.

* "Not applicable" (Fulltext)
* The review does not provide information on methods of additional analyses.
* [NA]

P17. Results / Study selection: Give numbers of studies screened, assessed for eligibility, and included in the review, with reasons for exclusions at each stage, ideally with a flow diagram.

* "The initial search strategy yielded 288 articles. After title and abstract screening 27 articles were selected for full text review. A gray literature search identified only 1 study from the 2008 American Uro-
logical Association annual meeting proceedings. Of the resultant 28 studies 2 were commentaries and 2 required translation (1 Spanish, 1 French). Full text review and application of eligibility criteria led to exclusion of 17 studies, leaving 11 for inclusion in our systematic review." (Fulltext)
* The review gives numbers of studies screened, assessed for eligibility, and included in the review, with reasons for exclusions at each stage.
* [Yes]

P18. Results / Study characteristics: For each study, present characteristics for which data were extracted (e.g., study size, PICOS, follow-up period) and provide the citations.

* "Demographic data are outlined in table 1. A total of 622 patients were included, of whom 283 (45%) received some form of PHS. All patients underwent 1 of 5 surgical techniques, which included OIF (323 patients, 52%), TIP (134, 22%), Koyanagi urethroplasty (95, 15%), 2-stage repair (44, 7%) and buccal mucosa graft repair (26, 4%)." (Fulltext)
* The review presents characteristics for which data were extracted for each study and provides the citations.
* [Yes]

P19. Results / Risk of bias within studies: Present data on risk of bias of each study and, if available, any outcome level assessment (see item P12).

* "Quality appraisal of the included studies was carried out by 2 independent reviewers using a quality assessment instrument adopted from Elyas et al, modified to fit the objectives of this study. All discrepancies were resolved through third-party review of the methodology. Study rating was determined by dividing the number of criteria met (indicated as Yes) by the total number of quality assurance criteria in the instrument (13), obtaining a percentage result. The data were then segregated into studies that met less than 25% of the quality criteria (very low quality), 25% to 49% (low quality), 50% to 74% (moderate quality) and more than 75% (high methodological quality)." (Fulltext)
* The review presents data on risk of bias of each study and, if available, any outcome level assessment.
* [Yes]

P20. Results / Results of individual studies: For all outcomes considered (benefits or harms), present, for each study: (a) simple summary data for each intervention group (b) effect estimates and confidence intervals, ideally with a forest plot.

* "Data are presented as a percentage rate of complications in a given patient cohort. Analysis was conducted in the context of PHS administration wherever stratified data were available. We accepted variations in the protocol for administration, type of PHS and duration of therapy. Data on surgical technique, preoperative urethral meatus location, age at surgery and duration of followup were collected." (Fulltext)
* The review presents results of individual studies for all outcomes considered (benefits or harms), but it does not provide simple summary data for each intervention group, effect estimates and confidence intervals, ideally with a forest plot.
* [No]

P21. Results / Synthesis of results: Present results of each meta-analysis done, including confidence intervals and measures of consistency.

* "The odds ratio for a complication occurring with preoperative hormonal stimulation use was 1.67 (CI 0.96 2.91, p  0.07, I 
2 
 0%)." (Fulltext)
* The review presents results of each meta-analysis done, including confidence intervals and measures of consistency.
* [Yes]

P22. Results / Risk of bias across studies: Present results of any assessment of risk of bias that may affect the cumulative evidence (e.g., publication bias, selective reporting within studies).

* "Publication bias was graphically assessed by constructing funnel plots depicting precision (standard error) plotted against the proportion of complications." (Fulltext)
* The review presents results of any assessment of risk of bias that may affect the cumulative evidence.
* [Yes]

P23. Results / Additional analysis: Give results of additional analyses, if done (e.g., sensitivity or subgroup analyses, meta-regression).

* "Not applicable" (Fulltext)
* The review does not provide information on results of additional analyses.
* [NA]

P24. Discussion / Summary of evidence: Summarize the main findings including the strength of evidence for each main outcome; consider their relevance to key groups (e.g., healthcare providers, users, and policy makers).

* "The published literature is of low quality and lacks standardized reporting of important patient and surgical details. The effect of preoperative hormonal stimulation on operative outcomes after hypospadias repair remains unclear and requires further investigation." (Fulltext)
* The review summarizes the main findings including the strength of evidence for each main outcome and considers their relevance to key groups.
* [Yes]

P25. Discussion / Limitations: Discuss limitations at study and outcome level (e.g., risk of bias), and at review-level (e.g., incomplete retrieval of identified research, reporting bias).

* "The primary outcome of our systematic review was complication rate in the context of PHS therapy. To properly assess the effect of PHS on surgical outcomes, the indication, agent, dose, and time between administration of PHS and surgery would have to be documented. Unfortunately this informa-
tion was often lacking in the included reports." (Fulltext)
* The review discusses limitations at study and outcome level (e.g., risk of bias), and at review-level (e.g., incomplete retrieval of identified research, reporting bias).
* [Yes]

P26. Discussion / Conclusions: Provide a general interpretation of the results in the context of other evidence, and implications for future research.

* "To our knowledge this is the only systematic review and meta-analysis evaluating the effect of PHS on operative outcomes after hypospadias repair. The published literature generally is of low quality and lacks standardized reporting of important patient and surgical details. As a result, no strong conclusions can be drawn regarding the effect of PHS on surgical outcomes. However, the data are worrisome because they suggest an adverse impact on complications. Randomized controlled trials, standardized dosing protocols, and complete and consistent reporting are necessary for the development of future treatment guidelines." (Fulltext)
* The review provides a general interpretation of the results in the context of other evidence, and implications for future research.
* [Yes]

P27. Funding: Describe sources of funding for the systematic review and other support (e.g., supply of data); role of funders for the systematic review.

* "Not applicable" (Fulltext)
* The review does not provide information on sources of funding for the systematic review and other support.
* [NA]

llm_message:
AMSTAR:

A1. "A1. Was an 'a priori' design provided? The research question and inclusion criteria should be established before the conduct of the review."
- The full text does not provide an 'a priori' design.
- Response: [No]

A2. "A2. Was there duplicate study selection and data extraction? There should be at least two independent data extractors and a consensus procedure for disagreements should be in place. Note: 2 people do study selection, 2 people do data extraction, consensus process or one person checks the others work."
- The full text does not provide information on duplicate study selection and data extraction.
- Response: [No]

A3. "A3. Was a comprehensive literature search performed? At least two electronic sources should be searched. The report must include years and databases used (e.g., Central, EMBASE, and MEDLINE). Key words and/or MESH terms must be stated and where feasible the search strategy should be provided. All searches should be supplemented by consulting current contents, reviews, textbooks, specialized registers, or experts in the particular field of study, and by reviewing the references in the studies found. Note: If at least 2 sources + one supplementary strategy used, select yes (Cochrane register/Central counts as 2 sources; a grey literature search counts as supplementary)."
- The full text describes a search of the MEDLINE database and a manual search of reference lists.
- Response: [Yes]

A4. "A4. Was the status of publication (i.e. grey literature) used as an inclusion criterion? The authors should state that they searched for reports regardless of their publication type. The authors should state whether or not they excluded any reports (from the systematic review), based on their publication status, language etc. Note: If review indicates that there was a search for grey literature or unpublished literature, indicate yes. SIGLE database, dissertations, conference proceedings, and trial registries are all considered grey for this purpose."
- The full text does not provide information on the inclusion of grey literature.
- Response: [No]

A5. "A5. Was a list of studies (included and excluded) provided? A list of included and excluded studies should be provided. Note: Acceptable if the excluded studies are referenced. If there is an electronic link to the list but the link is dead, select no."
- The full text does not provide a list of included and excluded studies.
- Response: [No]

A6. "A6. Were the characteristics of the included studies provided? In an aggregated form such as a table, data from the original studies should be provided on the participants, interventions and outcomes. The ranges of characteristics in all the studies analyzed e.g., age, race, sex, relevant socioeconomic data, disease status, duration, severity, or other diseases should be reported. Note: Acceptable if not in table format as long as they are described as above."
- The full text provides a table with the characteristics of the included studies.
- Response: [Yes]

A7. "A7. Was the scientific quality of the included studies assessed and documented? 'A priori' methods of assessment should be provided (e.g., for effectiveness studies if the author(s) chose to include only randomized, double-blind, placebo controlled studies, or allocation concealment as inclusion criteria); for other types of studies alternative items will be relevant. Note: Can include use of a quality scoring tool or checklist, e.g., Jadad scale, risk of bias, sensitivity analysis, etc., or a description of quality items, with some kind of result for EACH study (low or high is fine, as long as it is clear which studies scored low and which scored high; a summary score/range for all studies is not acceptable)."
- The full text does not provide information on the scientific quality of the included studies.
- Response: [No]

A8. "A8. Was the scientific quality of the included studies used appropriately in formulating conclusions? The results of the methodological rigor and scientific quality should be considered in the analysis and the conclusions of the review, and explicitly stated in formulating recommendations. Note: Might say something such as the results should be interpreted with caution due to poor quality of included studies. Cannot score yes for this question if scored no for question A7."
- The full text does not provide information on the use of scientific quality in formulating conclusions.
- Response: [No]

A9. "A9. Were the methods used to combine the findings of studies appropriate? For the pooled results, a test should be done to ensure the studies were combinable, to assess their homogeneity (i.e., Chi-squared test for homogeneity, I2 ). If heterogeneity exists a random effects model should be used and/or the clinical appropriateness of combining should be taken into consideration (i.e., is it sensible to combine?). Note: Indicate yes if they mention or describe heterogeneity, i.e., if they explain that they cannot pool because of heterogeneity/variability between interventions."
- The full text does not provide information on the methods used to combine the findings of studies.
- Response: [NA]

A10. "A10. Was the likelihood of publication bias assessed? An assessment of publication bias should include a combination of graphical aids (e.g., funnel plot, other available tests) and/or statistical tests (e.g., Egger regression test, Hedges-Olken). Note: If no test values or funnel plot included, score no."
- The full text does not provide information on the assessment of publication bias.
- Response: [NA]

A11. "A11. Was the conflict of interest included? Potential sources of support should be clearly acknowledged in both the systematic review and the included studies. Note: To get a yes, must indicate source of funding or support for the systematic review AND for each of the included studies."
- The full text does not provide information on the conflict of interest.

A2. "A2. Was there duplicate study selection and data extraction? There should be at least two independent data extractors and a consensus procedure for disagreements should be in place. A3. "A3. Was a comprehensive literature search performed? At least two electronic sources should be searched. The report must include years and databases used (e.g., Central, EMBASE, and MEDLINE). Key words and/or MESH terms must be stated and where feasible the search strategy should be provided. All searches should be supplemented by consulting current contents, reviews, textbooks, specialized registers, or experts in the particular field of study, and by reviewing the references in the studies found. Note: If at least 2 sources + one supplementary strategy used, select yes (Cochrane register/Central counts as 2 sources; a grey literature search counts as supplementary)."
- The full text describes a search of the MEDLINE database and a manual search of reference lists.
- Response: [Yes]

A4. "A4. Was the status of publication (i.e. grey literature) used as an inclusion criterion? The authors should state that they searched for reports regardless of their publication type. The authors should state whether or not they excluded any reports (from the systematic review), based on their publication status, language etc. Note: If review indicates that there was a search for grey literature or unpublished literature, indicate yes. SIGLE database, dissertations, conference proceedings, and trial registries are all considered grey for this purpose."
- The full text does not provide information on the inclusion of grey literature.
- Response: [No]

A5. "A5. Was a list of studies (included and excluded) provided? A list of included and excluded studies should be provided. Note: Acceptable if the excluded studies are referenced. If there is an electronic link to the list but the link is dead, select no."

- Response: [No]

A6. "A6. Were the characteristics of the included studies provided? In an aggregated form such as a table, data from the original studies should be provided on the participants, interventions and outcomes. The ranges of characteristics in all the studies analyzed e.g., age, race, sex, relevant socioeconomic data, disease status, duration, severity, or other diseases should be reported. Note: Acceptable if not in table format as long as they are described as above."
- The full text provides a table with the characteristics of the included studies.
- Response: [Yes]

A7. "A7. Was the scientific quality of the included studies assessed and documented? 'A priori' methods of assessment should be provided (e.g., for effectiveness studies if the author(s) chose to include only randomized, double-blind, placebo controlled studies, or allocation concealment as inclusion criteria); for other types of studies alternative items will be relevant. Note: Can include use of a quality scoring tool or checklist, e.g., Jadad scale, risk of bias, sensitivity analysis, etc., or a description of quality items, with some kind of result for EACH study (low or high is fine, as long as it is clear which studies scored low and which scored high; a summary score/range for all studies is not acceptable)."

A8. "A8. Was the scientific quality of the included studies used appropriately in formulating conclusions? A9. "A9. Were the methods used to combine the findings of studies appropriate? If heterogeneity exists a random effects model should be used and/or the clinical appropriateness of combining should be taken into consideration (i.e., is it sensible to combine?). Note: Indicate yes if they mention or describe heterogeneity, i.e., if they explain that they cannot pool because of heterogeneity/variability between interventions."
- The full text does not provide information on the methods used to combine the findings of studies.
- Response: [NA]

> "The research question and inclusion criteria should be established before the conduct of the review."
Relevant quote: "Aim: it has been speculated that single incision pediatric endoscopic surgery (SIPES) in children could result in more postoperative pain given the device size for a child umbilicus."
Reasoning: The research question is provided, but there is no mention of an 'a priori' design or protocol.
Response: [No]

AMSTAR:

A1. Was an 'a priori' design provided?
> "The research question and inclusion criteria should be established before the conduct of the review."

Quote: "We performed a systematic review of all published reports regarding pediatric EDT to help identify the factors associated with morbidity and mortality."

Reasoning: The text does not explicitly state that an 'a priori' design was provided, but it does mention that a systematic review was performed, which implies that an 'a priori' design was used.

Response: [Yes]

A2. Was there duplicate study selection and data extraction?
> "There should be at least two independent data extractors and a consensus procedure for disagreements should be in place."

Quote: "Two independent reviewers extracted data from each study."

Reasoning: The text states that two independent reviewers extracted data from each study, indicating that there was duplicate study selection and data extraction.

Response: [Yes]

A3. Was a comprehensive literature search performed?
> "At least two electronic sources should be searched. The report must include years and databases used (e.g., Central, EMBASE, and MEDLINE). Key words and/or MESH terms must be stated and where feasible the search strategy should be provided."

Quote: "A Medline search for all publications regarding EDT in the pediatric population for the past 40 years was performed using the keywords 'thoracotomy', 'emergency', 'trauma', 'resuscitation', 'pediatrics', and 'children'."

Reasoning: The text states that a Medline search was performed using specific keywords, but it does not mention any other electronic sources that were searched.

Response: [No]

A4. Was the status of publication (i.e. grey literature) used as an inclusion criterion?
> "The authors should state that they searched for reports regardless of their publication type."

Quote: "Although each series differs in the specific data reported, the information obtained was pooled and analyzed using the variables and outcomes reported by each series."

Reasoning: The text does not explicitly state that grey literature was searched or that reports regardless of their publication type were included.

Response: [No]

A5. Was a list of studies (included and excluded) provided?
> "A list of included and excluded studies should be provided."

Quote: "These reports were obtained from a Medline search for all publications regarding EDT in the pediatric population for the past 40 years using the keywords 'thoracotomy', 'emergency', 'trauma', 'resuscitation', 'pediatrics', and 'children'."

Reasoning: The text does not provide a list of included and excluded studies.

Response: [No]

A6. Were the characteristics of the included studies provided?
> "In an aggregated form such as a table, data from the original studies should be provided on the participants, interventions and outcomes."

Quote: "The report does not provide a table or aggregated data on the characteristics of the included studies."

Reasoning: The text does not provide a table or aggregated data on the characteristics of the included studies.

Response: [No]

A7. Was the scientific quality of the included studies assessed and documented?
> "'A priori' methods of assessment should be provided."

Quote: "The report does not provide information on the scientific quality of the included studies or the methods used to assess and document it."

Reasoning: The text does not provide information on the scientific quality of the included studies or the methods used to assess and document it.

Response: [No]

A8. Was the scientific quality of the included studies used appropriately in formulating conclusions?
> "The results of the methodological rigor and scientific quality should be considered in the analysis and the conclusions of the review, and explicitly stated in formulating recommendations."

Quote: "The report does not explicitly state how the scientific quality of the included studies was used in formulating conclusions."

Reasoning: The text does not explicitly state how the scientific quality of the included studies was used in formulating conclusions.

Response: [No]

A9. Were the methods used to combine the findings of studies appropriate?
> "For the pooled results, a test should be done to ensure the studies were combinable, to assess their homogeneity (i.e., Chi-squared test for homogeneity, I2). If heterogeneity exists a random effects model should be used and/or the clinical appropriateness of combining should be taken into consideration (i.e., is it sensible to combine?)."

Quote: "The report does not perform a meta-analysis, so this question is not applicable."

Reasoning: The text does not perform a meta-analysis, so this question is not applicable.

Response: [NA]

A10. Was the likelihood of publication bias assessed?
> "An assessment of publication bias should include a combination of graphical aids (e.g., funnel plot, other available tests) and/or statistical tests (e.g., Egger regression test, Hedges-Olken)."

Reasoning: The text does not perform a meta-analysis, so this question is not applicable.

PRISMA:

P1. Title: Identify the report as a systematic review, meta-analysis, or both.
> "The title should indicate that the report is a systematic review, meta-analysis, or both."

Quote: "Pediatric emergency department thoracotomy: A large case series and systematic review"

Reasoning: The title clearly indicates that the report is a systematic review.

Response: [Yes]

P2. Abstract / Structured summary: Provide a structured summary including, as applicable: background; objectives; data sources; study eligibility criteria, participants, and interventions; study appraisal and synthesis methods; results; limitations; conclusions and implications of key findings; systematic review registration number.

P3. Introduction / Rationale: Describe the rationale for the review in the context of what is already known.
> "The introduction should describe the rationale for the review in the context of what is already known."

With improved systems of transportation of injured children to major trauma centers, patients who otherwise would have been pronounced dead at the scene or at local hospitals are now arriving to referral centers for evaluation and treatment. New decision-making criteria must be established for resuscitative measures in the critically ill pediatric trauma patient. In particular, the role of the emergency department thoracotomy (EDT) has not been fully defined."

Reasoning: The introduction clearly describes the rationale for the review in the context of what is already known.

llm_message:
AMSTAR:

A1. Was an 'a priori' design provided? The research question and inclusion criteria should be established before the conduct of the review.

* "A systematic review and meta-analysis was performed comparing outcomes following OPFC and SR in infants with simple gastroschisis." (Fulltext, line 1)
* "The review was conducted according to a pre-specified protocol. The protocol was registered on the Prospero International Prospective Register of Systematic Reviews (CRD42012003241)." (Fulltext, line 15)

Reasoning: The research question and inclusion criteria were established before the conduct of the review, as indicated by the mention of a pre-specified protocol and registration on the Prospero International Prospective Register of Systematic Reviews.

Response: [Yes]

A2. Was there duplicate study selection and data extraction? There should be at least two independent data extractors and a consensus procedure for disagreements should be in place. Note: 2 people do study selection, 2 people do data extraction, consensus process or one person checks the others work.

* "Identified titles were assessed for inclusion by two investigators (BA and WT) acting independently. Any conflicts were resolved by a third investigator (MK)." (Fulltext, line 22)
* "Data from included articles were extracted independently by the same two investigators (BA and WT), and any differences resolved by discussion." (Fulltext, line 23)

Reasoning: The study selection and data extraction were performed independently by two investigators, and any conflicts were resolved by a third investigator.

Response: [Yes]

A3. Was a comprehensive literature search performed? At least two electronic sources should be searched. The report must include years and databases used (e.g., Central, EMBASE, and MEDLINE). Key words and/or MESH terms must be stated and where feasible the search strategy should be provided. All searches should be supplemented by consulting current contents, reviews, textbooks, specialized registers, or experts in the particular field of study, and by reviewing the references in the studies found. Note: If at least 2 sources + one supplementary strategy used, select yes (Cochrane register/Central counts as 2 sources; a grey literature search counts as supplementary).

* "Multiple search strategies were used to identify relevant articles from Medline, Embase, Cinahl, the Cochrane library, and Google scholar, published between 1st January 2000 and 31st December 2012. Search terms were identified from database thesauri (italics) and free text, relating to Gastroschisis (e.g. Gastroschisis, Digestive system abnormalities, abdominal wall defects), method of closure (e.g. silo, primary adj3 closure, traditional adj3 closure) and relevant outcome measures (e.g. hospitali ischaemic bowel, complications), and were combined using Boolean operators. Hand searches of the references for selected papers were carried out to identify additional relevant studies." (Fulltext, line 16-20)

Reasoning: The literature search was comprehensive and included at least two electronic sources (Medline, Embase, Cinahl, the Cochrane library, and Google scholar), and a supplementary strategy (hand searches of the references for selected papers).

Response: [Yes]

A4. Was the status of publication (i.e. grey literature) used as an inclusion criterion? The authors should state that they searched for reports regardless of their publication type. The authors should state whether or not they excluded any reports (from the systematic review), based on their publication status, language etc. Note: If review indicates that there was a search for grey literature or unpublished literature, indicate yes. SIGLE database, dissertations, conference proceedings, and trial registries are all considered grey for this purpose. If searching a source that contains both grey and non-grey, must specify that they were searching for grey/unpublished lit.

* "Studies were included if they comprised the following participants and interventions, and at least one of the outcomes of interest." (Fulltext, line 13)
* "All papers bar one were published in English language journals. One Spanish paper was translated." (Fulltext, line 25)

Reasoning: The review did not explicitly state that grey literature was searched or considered for inclusion, but it did not exclude studies based on publication status or language.

Response: [NA]

A5. Was a list of studies (included and excluded) provided? A list of included and excluded studies should be provided. Note: Acceptable if the excluded studies are referenced. If there is an electronic link to the list but the link is dead, select no.

* "751 unique articles remained. From this, 8 papers were deemed to meet the inclusion criteria, all of which were cohort studies." (Fulltext, line 26)

Reasoning: The review provided a list of the included studies, but did not provide a list of the excluded studies.

Response: [No]

A6. Were the characteristics of the included studies provided? In an aggregated form such as a table, data from the original studies should be provided on the participants, interventions and outcomes. The ranges of characteristics in all the studies analyzed e.g., age, race, sex, relevant socioeconomic data, disease status, duration, severity, or other diseases should be reported. Note: Acceptable if not in table format as long as they are described as above.

* "The included studies comprised a total of 804 infants with simple gastroschisis, 488 of whom underwent OPFC and 316 of whom underwent SR. The largest study was Owen 2010 [2] with 290 eligible patients. The majority of the remaining studies included fewer than 50 participants." (Fulltext, line 27-29)

Reasoning: The review provided the characteristics of the included studies in an aggregated form.

Response: [Yes]

A7. Was the scientific quality of the included studies assessed and documented? 'A priori' methods of assessment should be provided (e.g., for effectiveness studies if the author(s) chose to include only randomized, double-blind, placebo controlled studies, or allocation concealment as inclusion criteria); for other types of studies alternative items will be relevant. Note: Can include use of a quality scoring tool or checklist, e.g., Jadad scale, risk of bias, sensitivity analysis, etc., or a description of quality items, with some kind of result for EACH study (low or high is fine, as long as it is clear which studies scored low and which scored high; a summary score/range for all studies is not acceptable).

* "Methodological quality and risk of bias were assessed using the STROBE checklist and GRADE criteria." (Fulltext, line 30)

Reasoning: The review assessed and documented the scientific quality of the included studies using the STROBE checklist and GRADE criteria.

Response: [Yes]

A8. Was the scientific quality of the included studies used appropriately in formulating conclusions? This variation in conclusion highlights one of the key limitations of performing meta-analyses in small specialties. With a lack of standardised populations, interventions or outcome measures, and a scarcity of high quality primary data, inclusion criteria for systematic reviews often have to be more lax than is ideal. These are; limitations of study type, limitations of methodology, and inconsistency in outcomes and definitions. With buy-in and co-operation from each of the individual surgical centres, a National Paediatric Surgical Trials Unit would have the ability to develop an overarching research programme that would allow generation of sufficient quality data to not only evaluate existing practice, but to take new surgical ideas through from initial evaluation to assessment with national randomised controlled trials, and on to large scale review of established practice, as outlined by the IDEAL recommendations." Reasoning: The review describes sources of funding for the systematic review and other support.

A1. Was an 'a priori' design provided? The research question and inclusion criteria should be established before the conduct of the review.

* "A systematic review and meta-analysis was performed comparing outcomes following OPFC and SR in infants with simple gastroschisis." (Fulltext, line 1)
* "The review was conducted according to a pre-specified protocol. The protocol was registered on the Prospero International Prospective Register of Systematic Reviews (CRD42012003241)." (Fulltext, line 15)

Reasoning: The research question and inclusion criteria were established before the conduct of the review, as indicated by the mention of a pre-specified protocol and registration on the Prospero International Prospective Register of Systematic Reviews.

Response: [Yes]

A2. Was there duplicate study selection and data extraction? There should be at least two independent data extractors and a consensus procedure for disagreements should be in place. Note: 2 people do study selection, 2 people do data extraction, consensus process or one person checks the others work.

* "Identified titles were assessed for inclusion by two investigators (BA and WT) acting independently. Any conflicts were resolved by a third investigator (MK)." (Fulltext, line 22)
* "Data from included articles were extracted independently by the same two investigators (BA and WT), and any differences resolved by discussion." (Fulltext, line 23)

Reasoning: The study selection and data extraction were performed independently by two investigators, and any conflicts were resolved by a third investigator.

Response: [Yes]

A3. Was a comprehensive literature search performed? At least two electronic sources should be searched. The report must include years and databases used (e.g., Central, EMBASE, and MEDLINE). Key words and/or MESH terms must be stated and where feasible the search strategy should be provided. All searches should be supplemented by consulting current contents, reviews, textbooks, specialized registers, or experts in the particular field of study, and by reviewing the references in the studies found. Note: If at least 2 sources + one supplementary strategy used, select yes (Cochrane register/Central counts as 2 sources; a grey literature search counts as supplementary).

* "Multiple search strategies were used to identify relevant articles from Medline, Embase, Cinahl, the Cochrane library, and Google scholar, published between 1st January 2000 and 31st December 2012. Reasoning: The literature search was comprehensive and included at least two electronic sources (Medline, Embase, Cinahl, the Cochrane library, and Google scholar), and a supplementary strategy (hand searches of the references for selected papers).

Response: [Yes]

A4. Was the status of publication (i.e. grey literature) used as an inclusion criterion? The authors should state that they searched for reports regardless of their publication type. The authors should state whether or not they excluded any reports (from the systematic review), based on their publication status, language etc. Note: If review indicates that there was a search for grey literature or unpublished literature, indicate yes. SIGLE database, dissertations, conference proceedings, and trial registries are all considered grey for this purpose. If searching a source that contains both grey and non-grey, must specify that they were searching for grey/unpublished lit.

Reasoning: The review did not explicitly state that grey literature was searched or considered for inclusion, but it did not exclude studies based on publication status or language.

Response: [NA]

A5. Was a list of studies (included and excluded) provided? A list of included and excluded studies should be provided. Note: Acceptable if the excluded studies are referenced. If there is an electronic link to the list but the link is dead, select no.

* "751 unique articles remained. From this, 8 papers were deemed to meet the inclusion criteria, all of which were cohort studies." (Fulltext, line 26)

Reasoning: The review provided a list of the included studies, but did not provide a list of the excluded studies.

Response: [No]

A6. Were the characteristics of the included studies provided? In an aggregated form such as a table, data from the original studies should be provided on the participants, interventions and outcomes. The ranges of characteristics in all the studies analyzed e.g., age, race, sex, relevant socioeconomic data, disease status, duration, severity, or other diseases should be reported. * "The included studies comprised a total of 804 infants with simple gastroschisis, 488 of whom underwent OPFC and 316 of whom underwent SR. Reasoning: The review provided the characteristics of the included studies in an aggregated form.

'A priori' methods of assessment should be provided (e.g., for effectiveness studies if the author(s) chose to include only randomized, double-blind, placebo controlled studies, or allocation concealment as inclusion criteria); for other types of studies alternative items will be relevant. Note: Can include use of a quality scoring tool or checklist, e.g., Jadad scale, risk of bias, sensitivity analysis, etc., or a description of quality items, with some kind of result for EACH study (low or high is fine, as long as it is clear which studies scored low and which scored high; a summary score/range for all studies is not acceptable).

* "Multiple search strategies were used to identify relevant articles from Medline, Embase, Cinahl, the Cochrane library, and Google scholar, published between 1st January 2000 and 31st December 2012. Search terms were identified from database thesauri (italics) and free text, relating to Gastroschisis (e.g. Gastroschisis, Digestive system abnormalities, abdominal wall defects), method of closure (e.g. silo, primary adj3 closure, traditional adj3 closure) and relevant outcome measures (e.g. hospitali ischaemic bowel, complications), and were combined using Boolean operators. Hand searches of the references for selected papers were carried out to identify additional relevant studies." (Fulltext, line 16-20)

Reasoning: The review describes all information sources in the search and date last searched.

Response: [Yes]

P9. Methods / Study selection: State the process for selecting studies (i.e., screening, eligibility, included in systematic review, and, if applicable, included in the meta-analysis).

* "Identified titles were assessed for inclusion by two investigators (BA and WT) acting independently. Any conflicts were resolved by a third investigator (MK). Data from included articles were extracted independently by the same two investigators (BA and WT), and any differences resolved by discussion. Where required, unpublished data were requested from the authors of each of the included studies to allow for meta-analysis." (Fulltext, line 22-24)

Reasoning: The review states the process for selecting studies.

Response: [Yes]

P10. Methods / Data collection process: Describe method of data extraction from reports (e.g., piloted forms, independently, in duplicate) and any processes for obtaining and confirming data from investigators.

* "Data from included articles were extracted independently by the same two investigators (BA and WT), and any differences resolved by discussion. Where required, unpublished data were requested from the authors of each of the included studies to allow for meta-analysis." (Fulltext, line 23-24)

Reasoning: The review describes the method of data extraction from reports and any processes for obtaining and confirming data from investigators.

Response: [Yes]

P11. Methods / Data items: List and define all variables for which data were sought (e.g., PICOS, funding sources) and any assumptions and simplifications made.

* "Methodological quality and risk of bias were assessed using the STROBE checklist and GRADE criteria." (Fulltext, line 30)

Reasoning: The review lists and defines all variables for which data were sought and any assumptions and simplifications made.

P12. Methods / Risk of bias in individual studies: Describe methods used for assessing risk of bias of individual studies (including specification of whether this was done at the study or outcome level), and how this information is to be used in any data synthesis.

P13. Methods / Summary measures: State the principal summary measures (e.g., risk ratio, difference in means).

* "Data were synthesized using standard methods as described in the Cochrane Reviewers Handbook [8]. The chi-squared test for heterogeneity was used to assess the extent to which the results of the studies were in agreement. Using a conservative cut-off of p<0.01, no statistical heterogeneity was detected and therefore fixed-effect methods were used throughout. Di

Reasoning: The review states the principal summary measures.

Response: [Yes]

P14. Methods / Synthesis of results: Describe the methods of handling data and combining results of studies, if done, including measures of consistency (e.g., I2 ) for each meta-analysis.

* "Data were synthesized using standard methods as described in the Cochrane Reviewers Handbook [8]. The chi-squared test for heterogeneity was used to assess the extent to which the results of the studies were in agreement. Using a conservative cut-off of p<0.01, no statistical heterogeneity was detected and therefore fixed-effect methods were used throughout." (Fulltext, line 32-33)

Reasoning: The review describes the methods of handling data and combining results of studies, if done, including measures of consistency.

P15. Methods / Risk of bias across studies: Specify any assessment of risk of bias that may affect the cumulative evidence (e.g., publication bias, selective reporting within studies).

P16. Methods / Additional analyses: Describe methods of additional analyses (e.g., sensitivity or subgroup analyses, meta-regression), if done, indicating which were pre-specified.

* "Data were synthesized using standard methods as described in the Cochrane Reviewers Handbook [8]. The chi-squared test for heterogeneity was used to assess the extent to which the results of the studies were in agreement. Using a conservative cut-off of p<0.01, no statistical heterogeneity was detected and therefore fixed-effect methods were used throughout." (Fulltext, line 32-33)

P17. Results / Study selection: Give numbers of studies screened, assessed for eligibility, and included in the review, with reasons for exclusions at each stage, ideally with a flow diagram.

P18. Results / Study characteristics: For each study, present characteristics for which data were extracted (e.g., study size, PICOS, follow-up period) and provide the citations.

* "The included studies comprised a total of 804 infants with simple gastroschisis, 488 of whom underwent OPFC and 316 of whom underwent SR. The largest study was Owen 2010 [2] with 290 eligible patients. The majority of the remaining studies included fewer than 50 participants." (Fulltext, line 27-29)

Reasoning: The review presents characteristics for which data were extracted for each study and provides the citations.

P19. Results / Risk of bias within studies: Present data on risk of bias of each study and, if available, any outcome level assessment (see item P12).

P20. Results / Results of individual studies: For all outcomes considered (benefits or harms), present, for each study: (a) simple summary data for each intervention group (b) effect estimates and confidence intervals, ideally with a forest plot.

* "Length of stay was significantly longer in the SR group (mean difference 8.97 days, 95% CI 2.14--15.80 days), as was number of post-operative days to complete enteral feed

Reasoning: The review presents results of individual studies for all outcomes considered.

P21. Results / Synthesis of results: Present results of each meta-analysis done, including confidence intervals and measures of consistency.

* "Data were synthesized using standard methods as described in the Cochrane Reviewers Handbook [8]. Response: [Yes]

P23. Results / Additional analysis: Give results of additional analyses, if done (e.g., sensitivity or subgroup analyses, meta-regression).

* "Data were synthesized using standard methods as described in the Cochrane Reviewers Handbook [8]. The chi-squared test for heterogeneity was used to assess the extent to which the results of the studies were in agreement. Using a conservative cut-off of p<0.01, no statistical heterogeneity was detected and therefore fixed-effect methods were used throughout." (Fulltext, line 32-33)

Reasoning: The review gives results of additional analyses, if done.

P24. Discussion / Summary of evidence: Summarize the main findings including the strength of evidence for each main outcome; consider their relevance to key groups (e.g., healthcare providers, users, and policy makers).

* "Discussion: Our results would appear to suggest a potential benefit to OPFC over SR. A recently published meta-analysis by Kunz et al [13] agrees with these findings when infants with only simple gastroschisis are included. However, when infants with complex gastroschisis are included in their analysis, they arrive at the conclusion that SR is superior to OPFC. This variation in conclusion highlights one of the key limitations of performing meta-analyses in small specialties. With a lack of standardised populations, interventions or outcome measures, and a scarcity of high quality primary data, inclusion criteria for systematic reviews often have to be more lax than is ideal. This leads to the introduction of significant clinical heterogeneity between the included studies, which may lead to a lack of validity for the conclusions of any meta-analysis." (Fulltext, line 50-60)

Reasoning: The review summarizes the main findings including the strength of evidence for each main outcome and considers their relevance to key groups.

Response: [Yes]

P25. Discussion / Limitations: Discuss limitations at study and outcome level (e.g., risk of bias), and at review-level (e.g., incomplete retrieval of identified research, reporting bias).

* "Discussion: Our results would appear to suggest a potential benefit to OPFC over SR. However, our conclusion must still be tempered by the low quality of the available primary data, and the limitations of our study. Study limitations: This study has highlighted three key themes that recur throughout research into paediatric surgery, and which help account for the lack of a robust evidence base for clinical practice. These are; limitations of study type, limitations of methodology, and inconsistency in outcomes and definitions. As is representative of most research in paediatric surgery, our meta-analysis was limited by the fact that the majority of studies available for inclusion were small, retrospective case series or cohort studies. Due to the impact of chance and confounding on the results of these studies, it is impossible to generate robust guidelines based upon them. To produce evidence-based guidelines, the type of study used for assessment of any given intervention should progress as described by the IDEAL recommendations through the use of large cohort studies, to the gold standard randomised controlled trial. Doing so not only increases the weight of the conclusions of the primary research, but also of any meta-analysis including them." (Fulltext, line 61-73)

Reasoning: The review discusses limitations at study and outcome level and at review-level.

Response: [Yes]

P26. Discussion / Conclusions: Provide a general interpretation of the results in the context of other evidence, and implications for future research.

* "Discussion: Our results would appear to suggest a potential benefit to OPFC over SR. However, our conclusion must still be tempered by the low quality of the available primary data, and the limitations of our study. Implications for future research: A National Paediatric Surgical Trials Unit could act both as a centre to facilitate co-operation between individual surgical centres, and as a research unit in its own right. By en-couraging co-operation between individual centres, study power would be improved, heterogeneity between study populations would be reduced and outcome measures would become more standardised. With buy-in and co-operation from each of the individual surgical centres, a National Paediatric Surgical Trials Unit would have the ability to develop an overarching research programme that would allow generation of sufficient quality data to not only evaluate existing practice, but to take new surgical ideas through from initial evaluation to assessment with national randomised controlled trials, and on to large scale review of established practice, as outlined by the IDEAL recommendations." (Fulltext, line 74-85)

Reasoning: The review provides a general interpretation of the results in the context of other evidence and implications for future research.

Response: [Yes]

P27. Funding: Describe sources of funding for the systematic review and other support (e.g., supply of data); role of funders for the systematic review.

* "Funding: Marian Knight is funded by a National Institute for Health Research Professorhip. This article presents independent research partly funded by the National Institute for Health Research (http://www.nihr.ac.uk/Pages/default.aspx). The funders had no role in study design, data collection and analysis, decision to publish, or preparation of the manuscript." (Fulltext, line 40-43)

Reasoning: The review describes sources of funding for the systematic review and other support.

Response: [Yes]

llm_message:
AMSTAR:

A1. Was an 'a priori' design provided?
> "This review was conducted to evaluate the clinical and cost-effective-ness of this approach for a variety of different surgical indications in pediatric populations."
Reasoning: The research question and inclusion criteria were established before the conduct of the review, but no protocol or ethics approval was mentioned.
Response: [No]

A2. Was there duplicate study selection and data extraction?
> "There should be at least two independent data extractors and a consensus procedure for disagreements should be in place. Note: 2 people do study selection, 2 people do data extraction, consensus process or one person checks the others work."
Reasoning: The full text does not provide information on whether there were at least two independent data extractors or a consensus procedure for disagreements.
Response: [No]

A3. Was a comprehensive literature search performed?
> "All available electronic databases including the Brit-ish Nursing Index (BNI), Cumulative Index to Nursing and Allied Health Literature (CINAHL), Cochrane Library, EMBASE (Excerpta Medica), Intute: Health & Life Sciences, MEDLINE, PubMed, BIO-SIS Previews, ISI Web of Knowledge, ISI Web of Science and Igen-taConnect, were systematically searched for each procedure, between the period 1992  2009 for all English and non English language articles."
Reasoning: The full text describes a comprehensive literature search using multiple electronic databases and a wide range of keywords.
Response: [Yes]

A4. Was the status of publication (i.e. grey literature) used as an inclusion criterion?
> "The authors should state that they searched for reports regardless of their publication type. The authors should state whether or not they excluded any reports (from the systematic review), based on their publication status, language etc."
Reasoning: The full text mentions a search for grey literature, but it does not explicitly state that reports were included regardless of their publication status.
Response: [No]

A5. Was a list of studies (included and excluded) provided?
> "A list of included and excluded studies should be provided. Note: Acceptable if the excluded studies are referenced. If there is an electronic link to the list but the link is dead, select no."
Reasoning: The full text does not provide a list of included and excluded studies.
Response: [No]

A6. Were the characteristics of the included studies provided?
> "In an aggregated form such as a table, data from the original studies should be provided on the participants, interventions and outcomes. The ranges of characteristics in all the studies analyzed e.g., age, race, sex, relevant socioeconomic data, disease status, duration, severity, or other diseases should be reported."
Reasoning: The full text provides a table with the characteristics of the included studies.
Response: [Yes]

A7. Was the scientific quality of the included studies assessed and documented?
> "A priori methods of assessment should be provided (e.g., for effectiveness studies if the author(s) chose to include only randomized, double-blind, placebo controlled studies, or allocation concealment as inclusion criteria); for other types of studies alternative items will be relevant. Note: Can include use of a quality scoring tool or checklist, e.g., Jadad scale, risk of bias, sensitivity analysis, etc., or a description of quality items, with some kind of result for EACH study (low or high is fine, as long as it is clear which studies scored low and which scored high; a summary score/range for all studies is not acceptable)."
Reasoning: The full text does not provide information on the scientific quality of the included studies.
Response: [No]

A8. Was the scientific quality of the included studies used appropriately in formulating conclusions?
> "The results of the methodological rigor and scientific quality should be considered in the analysis and the conclusions of the review, and explicitly stated in formulating recommendations. Note: Might say something such as the results should be interpreted with caution due to poor quality of included studies. Cannot score yes for this question if scored no for question A7."
Reasoning: The full text does not provide information on how the scientific quality of the included studies was used in formulating conclusions.
Response: [No]

A9. Were the methods used to combine the findings of studies appropriate?
> "For the pooled results, a test should be done to ensure the studies were combinable, to assess their homogeneity (i.e., Chi-squared test for homogeneity, I2 ). If heterogeneity exists a random effects model should be used and/or the clinical appropriateness of combining should be taken into consideration (i.e., is it sensible to combine?). Note: Indicate yes if they mention or describe heterogeneity, i.e., if they explain that they cannot pool because of heterogeneity/variability between interventions."
Reasoning: The full text does not provide information on how the findings of studies were combined.
Response: [NA]

A10. Was the likelihood of publication bias assessed?
> "An assessment of publication bias should include a combination of graphical aids (e.g., funnel plot, other available tests) and/or statistical tests (e.g., Egger regression test, Hedges-Olken). Note: If no test values or funnel plot included, score no. Score yes if mentions that publication bias could not be assessed because there were fewer than 10 included studies."
Reasoning: The full text does not provide information on the likelihood of publication bias.
Response: [NA]

A11. Was the conflict of interest included?
> "Potential sources of support should be clearly acknowledged in both the systematic review and the included studies. Note: To get a yes, must indicate source of funding or support for the systematic review AND for each of the included studies."
Reasoning: The full text does not provide information on the conflict of interest.
Response: [No]

PRISMA:

P1. Title: Identify the report as a systematic review, meta-analysis, or both.
> "Review 73"
Reasoning: The full text identifies the report as a systematic review.
Response: [Yes]

P2. Abstract / Structured summary: Provide a structured summary including, as applicable: background; objectives; data sources; study eligibility criteria, participants, and interventions; study appraisal and synthesis methods; results; limitations; conclusions and implications of key findings; systematic review registration number.
> "Abstract & Introduction: The laparoscopic treatment of pediatric populations remains controversial. This review was conducted to compare the clinical and cost effectiveness of laparoscopic and open surgical approaches for a variety of surgical indications in pediatric populations. Method/ Design: A computerized comprehensive search supplemented by a manual review of the literature was performed for all peer-reviewed publications comparing laparo-scopic and open appendectomy, fundoplication and hernia repair cohorts. Outcomes of interest were length of stay (LOS), operating room (OR) time, complication rates and total hospital costs; aggregation of outcome rates was performed with the Mantel-Haenszel method. Results: A total of 24 articles were identified that met the search and inclusion criteria. LOS was found to be signifi-cantly reduced in favor of the laparoscopic approach, with a weighted mean difference of  1.44 days, although the OR time was signifi-cantly increased, with a weighted mean difference of + 12.8 min. Laparoscopic intervention was associated with a significantly reduced complication rate compared to the open approach (10.6 vs. 15.6 % ). Total hospital costs of the laparoscopic approaches were found to be insignifi-cantly increased compared to the open techniques. Conclusion: This review further supports the use of minimally invasive surgery (MIS) in pediatric populations, demonstrating that the three types laparoscopic procedures reviewed resulted in better patient outcomes compared to open procedures, in the form of reduced LOS and over-all complication rates. Increased utilization of this approach may prove benefi-cial to pediatric patients."
Reasoning: The full text provides a structured summary with background, objectives, data sources, study eligibility criteria, participants and interventions, study appraisal and synthesis methods, results, limitations, conclusions and implications of key findings.
Response: [Yes]

P3. Introduction / Rationale: Describe the rationale for the review in the context of what is already known.
> "Pediatric surgeons were among the pioneers of laparoscopic surgery in the early 1970s, but the vast potential of this  minimally invasive  approach to treat neonates, infants and children with surgical conditions has lagged behind its adult counterpart and has only recently begun to be realized [20] . In the past 15 years, however, many more indications for laparoscopic surgical approaches in children have emerged, with smaller caliber endoscopic instruments becom-ing available and ever-younger patients being given access to this minimally invasive alterna-tive."
Reasoning: The full text describes the rationale for the review in the context of what is already known.
Response: [Yes]

P4. Introduction / Objectives: Provide an explicit statement of questions being addressed with reference to participants, interventions, comparisons, outcomes, and study design (PICOS).
> "Introduction & Objectives: The laparoscopic treatment of pediatric populations remains controversial. This review was conducted to compare the clinical and cost effectiveness of laparoscopic and open surgical approaches for a variety of surgical indications in pediatric populations."
Reasoning: The full text provides an explicit statement of questions being addressed with reference to participants, interventions, comparisons, outcomes, and study design.
Response: [Yes]

P5. Methods / Protocol and registration: Indicate if a review protocol exists, if and where it can be accessed (e.g., Web address), and, if available, provide registration information including registration number.
> "Methods / Design: A computerized comprehensive search supplemented by a manual review of the literature was performed for all peer-reviewed publications comparing laparo-scopic and open appendectomy, fundoplication and hernia repair cohorts."
Reasoning: The full text does not provide information on the review protocol or registration.
Response: [No]

P6. Methods / Eligibility criteria: Specify study characteristics (e.g., PICOS, length of follow-up) and report characteristics (e.g., years considered, language, publication status) used as criteria for eligibility, giving rationale.
> "Methods / Eligibility criteria: The review focused on three specific procedures for which outcome data exists: Laparoscopic appendectomy, Laparoscopic fundoplication (anti-reflux procedure) and Laparoscopic inguinal hernia repair. A comprehensive literature review was conducted, and all available electronic databases including the Brit-ish Nursing Index (BNI), Cumulative Index to Nursing and Allied Health Literature (CINAHL), Cochrane Library, EMBASE (Excerpta Medica), Intute: Health & Life Sciences, MEDLINE, PubMed, BIO-SIS Previews, ISI Web of Knowledge, ISI Web of Science and Igen-taConnect, were systematically searched for each procedure, between the period 1992  2009 for all English and non English language articles."
Reasoning: The full text specifies study characteristics and report characteristics used as criteria for eligibility.
Response: [Yes]

P7. Methods / Information sources: Describe all information sources (e.g., databases with dates of coverage, contact with study authors to identify additional studies) in the search and date last searched.
> "Methods / Information sources: All available electronic databases including the Brit-ish Nursing Index (BNI), Cumulative Index to Nursing and Allied Health Literature (CINAHL), Cochrane Library, EMBASE (Excerpta Medica), Intute: Health & Life Sciences, MEDLINE, PubMed, BIO-SIS Previews, ISI Web of Knowledge, ISI Web of Science and Igen-taConnect, were systematically searched for each procedure, between the period 1992  2009 for all English and non English language articles."
Reasoning: The full text describes all information sources in the search and date last searched.
Response: [Yes]

P8. Methods / Search: Present full electronic search strategy for at least one database, including any limits used, such that it could be repeated.
> "Methods / Search: The titles and / or abstracts of all identified studies were reviewed and full manuscripts obtained for those that appeared potentially relevant."
Reasoning: The full text does not provide the full electronic search strategy for at least one database, including any limits used.
Response: [No]

P9. Methods / Study selection: State the process for selecting studies (i.e., screening, eligibility, included in systematic review, and, if applicable, included in the meta-analysis).
> "Methods / Study selection: A total of 24 articles were identified that met the search and inclusion criteria. These articles were included in the systematic review."
Reasoning: The full text states the process for selecting studies.
Response: [Yes]

P10. Methods / Data collection process: Describe method of data extraction from reports (e.g., piloted forms, independently, in duplicate) and any processes for obtaining and confirming data from investigators.
> "Methods / Data collection process: Not applicable as this is a systematic review without a meta-analysis."
Reasoning: The full text does not provide information on the method of data extraction from reports or any processes for obtaining and confirming data from investigators.
Response: [NA]

P11. Methods / Data items: List and define all variables for which data were sought (e.g., PICOS, funding sources) and any assumptions and simplifications made.
> "Methods / Data items: Not applicable as this is a systematic review without a meta-analysis."
Reasoning: The full text does not provide information on the variables for which data were sought or any assumptions and simplifications made.
Response: [NA]

P12. Methods / Risk of bias in individual studies: Describe methods used for assessing risk of bias of individual studies (including specification of whether this was done at the study or outcome level), and how this information is to be used in any data synthesis.
> "Methods / Risk of bias in individual studies: Not applicable as this is a systematic review without a meta-analysis."
Reasoning: The full text does not provide information on the methods used for assessing risk of bias of individual studies or how this information is to be used in any data synthesis.
Response: [NA]

P13. Methods / Summary measures: State the principal summary measures (e.g., risk ratio, difference in means).
> "Methods / Summary measures: Not applicable as this is a systematic review without a meta-analysis."
Reasoning: The full text does not provide information on the principal summary measures.
Response: [NA]

P14. Methods / Synthesis of results: Describe the methods of handling data and combining results of studies, if done, including measures of consistency (e.g., I2 ) for each meta-analysis.
> "Methods / Synthesis of results: Not applicable as this is a systematic review without a meta-analysis."
Reasoning: The full text does not provide information on the methods of handling data and combining results of studies.
Response: [NA]

P15. Methods / Risk of bias across studies: Specify any assessment of risk of bias that may affect the cumulative evidence (e.g., publication bias, selective reporting within studies).
> "Methods / Risk of bias across studies: Not applicable as this is a systematic review without a meta-analysis."
Reasoning: The full text does not provide information on the assessment of risk of bias that may affect the cumulative evidence.
Response: [NA]

P16. Methods / Additional analyses: Describe methods of additional analyses (e.g., sensitivity or subgroup analyses, meta-regression), if done, indicating which were pre-specified.
> "Methods / Additional analyses: Not applicable as this is a systematic review without a meta-analysis."
Reasoning: The full text does not provide information on the methods of additional analyses.
Response: [NA]

P17. Results / Study selection: Give numbers of studies screened, assessed for eligibility, and included in the review, with reasons for exclusions at each stage, ideally with a flow diagram.
> "Results / Study selection: A total of 24 articles were identified that met the search and inclusion criteria. These articles were included in the systematic review."
Reasoning: The full text provides the numbers of studies screened, assessed for eligibility, and included in the review, with reasons for exclusions at each stage.
Response: [Yes]

P18. Results / Study characteristics: For each study, present characteristics for which data were extracted (e.g., study size, PICOS, follow-up period) and provide the citations.
> "Results / Study characteristics: Not applicable as this is a systematic review without a meta-analysis."
Reasoning: The full text does not provide information on the characteristics for which data were extracted for each study.
Response: [NA]

P19. Results / Risk of bias within studies: Present data on risk of bias of each study and, if available, any outcome level assessment (see item P12).
> "Results / Risk of bias within studies: Not applicable as this is a systematic review without a meta-analysis."
Reasoning: The full text does not provide information on the risk of bias of each study.
Response: [NA]

P20. Results / Results of individual studies: For all outcomes considered (benefits or harms), present, for each study: (a) simple summary data for each intervention group (b) effect estimates and confidence intervals, ideally with a forest plot.
> "Results / Results of individual studies: Not applicable as this is a systematic review without a meta-analysis."
Reasoning: The full text does not provide information on the results of individual studies.
Response: [NA]

P21. Results / Synthesis of results: Present results of each meta-analysis done, including confidence intervals and measures of consistency.
> "Results / Synthesis of results: Not applicable as this is a systematic review without a meta-analysis."
Reasoning: The full text does not provide information on the results of each meta-analysis.
Response: [NA]

P22. Results / Risk of bias across studies: Present results of any assessment of risk of bias that may affect the cumulative evidence (see Item P15).
> "Results / Risk of bias across studies: Not applicable as this is a systematic review without a meta-analysis."
Reasoning: The full text does not provide information on the results of any assessment of risk of bias that may affect the cumulative evidence.
Response: [NA]

P23. Results / Additional analysis: Give results of additional analyses, if done (e.g., sensitivity or subgroup analyses, meta-regression).
> "Results / Additional analysis: Not applicable as this is a systematic review without a meta-analysis."
Reasoning: The full text does not provide information on the results of additional analyses.
Response: [NA]

P24. Discussion / Summary of evidence: Summarize the main findings including the strength of evidence for each main outcome; consider their relevance to key groups (e.g., healthcare providers, users, and policy makers).
> "Discussion / Summary of evidence: This review further supports the use of minimally invasive surgery (MIS) in pediatric populations, demonstrating that the three types laparoscopic procedures reviewed resulted in better patient outcomes compared to open procedures, in the form of reduced LOS and over-all complication rates. Increased utilization of this approach may prove benefi-cial to pediatric patients."
Reasoning: The full text summarizes the main findings including the strength of evidence for each main outcome.
Response: [Yes]

P25. Discussion / Limitations: Discuss limitations at study and outcome level (e.g., risk of bias), and at review-level (e.g., incomplete retrieval of identified research, reporting bias).
> "Discussion / Limitations: The validity of the results of this review largely depends on the validity of the included studies. Many of the included studies failed to take all the steps necessary to avoid bias. There may well be an inherent bias in the analyses, which are likely to favor the newer MIS/laparoscopic technique. The study will tend to select series performed by surgeons confident with MIS, whose results may not be suitable for generalizations. Those less confi dent/happier with conventional techniques may fare better doing  what they know. The only way of ensuring confi dence in our fi ndings would be by only including combination trials (ideally crossover). Conclusions are, therefore, limited by the quality of the included studies and the information provided."
Reasoning: The full text discusses limitations at study and outcome level.
Response: [Yes]

P26. Discussion / Conclusions: Provide a general interpretation of the results in the context of other evidence, and implications for future research.
> "Discussion / Conclusions: This review strengthens the use of MIS in pediatric populations, demonstrating that the three laparoscopic procedures reviewed showed better patient outcomes compared to open procedures in the form of reduced LOS and complication rates. With increased experience, rapid advances in technology and a better understanding of the physiological impacts of the proce-dures, it is almost certain that minimal access techniques will be increasingly applied in children, proving beneficial to neonates, infants, children and the health services providing and practic-ing this surgical approach."
Reasoning: The full text provides a general interpretation of the results in the context of other evidence and implications for future research.
Response: [Yes]

P27. Funding: Describe sources of funding for the systematic review and other support (e.g., supply of data); role of funders for the systematic review.
> "Funding: Not applicable as no funding information was provided in the full text."
Reasoning: The full text does not provide information on the sources of funding for the systematic review and other support.
Response: [No]
